prose.s:
"... afterwards, I left the house. (ompo)
staṃ ostameṃ latau •
Having taken refuge with the Upādhyāya [teacher]... upādhy(ā)y(e)ṃ saim yā(mu) ///

Take me [as] (a lay follower), you venerable ones, [me] who has accepted the famous ones', the wise one of the Śākya's Law from now on (protecting it throughout [my whole]) life, [me] who has taken refuge, having become a believer!” /// (ṣanmīreṃ) (ñi)ś peṅksat śaulassoñc cwī ñem-klawissoṃnte śakke(ññepi) rṣākeṃ
(ts)e (p)elai(kne) ñakesa warñai śau(ltsa) (warñai) /// /// (śaultsa) (wä)rpoṣ pāssi • saimne ykuweṣ takarṣ«k»eṃ tatākaṣ

– “Listen, (oh) you venerable one, (to the 10 commandments [daśaśikṣāpadāni] which) by the famous one, the one who has thus come [= Tathāgata], by the worthy one [= Arhat], by the one (knowing) a(ll La)ws, for the one who has just left the house have been proclaimed, when for the novice (they are to be accepted) for the whole life. päkl«y»auṣ twe śaula
(ssu) causa ñem-klawi(s)s(ontsa) /// /// taiknesāk k(e)kamoṣ aṣanīkeṃntsa ysomo (p)o pelai
(knenta) (kärsoṣsa) (mä)ntrākka ostameṃ ltuweṣ(epi) /// /// (śak) (śikṣapā)tänta ākṣuwa • ente ṣanmīreṃntse śaul(tsa) (warñai) ///

(Which ten [commandments]? 1. Refraining from killing living beings), [this is a] commandment (for a novice).
/// (ṣanmīreṃntse) (śi)kṣapāt

Therefore you (shall) your whole life, (refrain from deliberately taking the life of) a living be(ing) (not even a worm[?] or an ant[?]!) tane t(a)ñ ś(au)ltsa warñai ono(lmeṃ)
///
Whatever [the circumstances], do not go beyond such a point! [i.e. become guilty of such an offence]! /// ·k·ṣ·ts mäkte kca twe ce te-yäknece īke mā k(āt)k(at)

(If you accept [this], say:) "I accept (this)." (kwri) (warpa)
(tar) (poñ) (ce) w(ä)rpanamar
Refr(aining from taking what has) not (been given,) [this is a] commandment for a novice. a(nāyätte) (ailyñe) /// /// (nar)käṣälyñe ṣanmīreṃtse śikṣapāt

Therefore your whole life you shall not take what has not been given [and is] someone else's property deliberately in thievish thought, not even a small piece of thread. tane t(a)ñ ś(au)l
lts(a) w(ar)ñ(ai) päknāmo anāyätte ketara ṣä(ñ) (waipecce) /// (mā) (pra)lle lykuññe palskosa postaññe rano ñreṣṣe peṅke

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 b1 b2 b3 b4

comments.comment: The text shows some careless spellings: takarṣeṃ for takarṣkeṃ (); päklauṣ for päklyauṣ ().
[[PK NS 175]]; ; for Sanskrit see , for Sanskrit and Chinese and for Tumšuqese ;

The identification, ordering and extensive supplementation of the fragments of leaves 9-11 ( – ) is facilitated largely by parallel texts from Sanskrit Buddhist literature. Thus a1-2 is relatively closely matched by the Sanskrit text as restored from fragments of Turfan mss. by , and a2 – b3 may be compared with a Sanskrit text, also restored from Turfan fragments by . The former of the two is a section of text that can be found repeatedly in the Buddhist Sanskrit-tradition, such as CPS 16.16, 17.13, 22.15, 27f.22, NidSa 20.17, ŚPrSū 111, BimbSū 143. The Sanskrit text mentioned by deviates slightly from these as does the Chinese parallel having five commandments [pañcaśikṣāpadāni]; see . Beyond this, a further parallel can be found, which surprisingly enough, and except for a few minor deviations, is remarkably close to the Tocharian text, and which therefore contributes greatly to supplementing our text here. It is a Tumšuqese Karmavācanā text (cf. ; for further reading) which from line 12-62 conforms almost verbatim to a1 – a3. Further important supplementations are owed to the TB fragments and [[PK NS 175]]. Certain deviations are caused by the fact that in the various versions occasionally different groups of persons are addressed. Thus the Sanskrit parts, the Tumšuqese text and contain formulas directed at lay followers (male, not female, as wrongly identified by ), while our text here contains directives for novices. The small fragment [[PK NS 175]] does not allow for any closer designation in this respect.

The text of the first five commandments of the Tocharian version could be largely completed with the help of the Skt. text supplied in , as well as – at least for commandments 1-3 – that of the Tumšuqese KaVā text. As for commandments 6-10, the Indic parallel versions (such as the Bhikṣukarmavākya, which belongs to the Mūlasarvāstivādin school) offer no more than mere lists of offences. For the Chinese Sarvāstivādin version cf. and . When one compares the Tocharian version with the Sanskrit text from the Bhikṣukarmavākya (p. 21) and the Pāli text from the Mahāvagga (I.56) the following picture emerges:

While commandments 1-4 – the supplementations of the Toch. text may be considered certain – do agree quite well in the various versions, commandments 5, 7, 8 (the Toch. text may be supplemented with certainty) and 9 display a number of differences in content, which render a persistent equation of the Tocharian sections with their respective counterparts in the Skt. and Pāli versions impossible.
The supplementations and commentaries follow .
(upāsakeṃ ñi)ś peṅksat: a shortened version of this request for acceptance as a lay follower is attested, in metrical form, in the Udānālaṅkāra fragment b3 and in the parallel text b2.
According to : iv-v the ms. either comes from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

This leaf consists of two larger fragments: the left side around the string hole, about 9-10 cm wide, in 8 pieces, partly preserved only in individual layers. The right side, about 15 cm wide, in 7 pieces. Between the two fragments about 5 cm are missing. The leaf number is not preserved.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2-3.
This leaf is in hand 1.
Note the virāma spelling inside the compound ñem-klawissu.
There is a gap of 7-8 akṣaras at the end of the first fragment, and there is blank space amounting to two akṣaras between ñem and klawisso[ṃ]nte.

(ompo)staṃ ostameṃ latau refers to the vow of following. On this cf. Bhu 21, 6-7: taṃ bhagavantaṃ śākyamuniṃ śākyasiṃhaṃ śākyādhirājaṃ tathāgatam arhantaṃ samyaksaṃbuddhaṃ pravrajitaṃ anupravrajāmi “The exalted one, the śākya-wise one, the śākya-lion, the overlord of the śākyas, the tathāgata, the holy one (and) entirely enlightened one, who has (also) gone forth, I follow.” (transl. cf. ).

(p)elai(kne) ... (wä)rpoṣ pāssi: for the construction of wärp- with infinitive cf. e.g. : a 3: wärpāt p(tāñkät ārkiśoṣṣis krant märkampal āksis(s)i “The Buddha has consented to teach the good Law to the world” and 4: kusne ñaktañ naivāsikāñ tri ñemintu pās(s)i wräpoṣ “Which gods [and] Naivāsikas, [who have] consented to guard the three jewels”. a 2 contains a TA parallel to b4 ((śau)ltsa pāssi wärpoṣ = a2 here (śaultsa wä)rpoṣ pāssi): āṣtraṃ pāpṣuneṣiṃ wkäṃ śolā pāssi wärporäṣ päknāmo kotnaṣ “(the third who) purposefully breaks the pure manner of [moral] conduct that he had intended to keep [up his] entire life” (supplementation and translation ).
There is a gap of 7-8 akṣaras at the end of the first fragment.
There is a gap of approximately 9 akṣaras at the end of the first fragment and due to a knothole blank space between taiknesāk and k(e)kamoṣ.

ñem-klawi(s)s(ontsa) = Skt. bhagavat, taiknesāk k(e)kamoṣ = Skt. tathāgata, aṣanīkeṃntsa = Skt. , and ysomo (p)o pelai(knenta kärsoṣsa) “he who, perfectly and plainly, knows all the Dharmas” = samyaksaṃbuddha (cf. TA kälymeyā ysomo puk märkapaläntu kärso and Tumšuqese andastai biśe dāte haṅgaṅgu räsanda). For these epithets of the Buddha cf. Mvy. § 1 (Tathāgatasya paryāyanāmāni). For an explanation of bhagavat cf. e.g. Mahāprajñāpāramitāśāstra I, p. 115f., for tathāgata cf. ibid p. 126, and for samyaksaṃbuddha cf. ibid. p. 127. In the Visuddhimagga, p. 201, sammāsambuddho is explained with sammā sāmañ ca sabbadhammānaṃ pana buddhattā.
There is a gap of approximately 9 akṣaras in the middle of this line to the end of the first fragment; 5 akṣaras are missing to the end of this line.
About 25 akṣaras are missing from the beginning of this line.
Skt. varttitavyam seems to be the equivalent of TB sportolle. Cf. : b3 maithunaṃ [sic!] saṃyog sutärsa warñai ṣamāññe parā(kä)ṣṣeñcaṃ sutarṣṣeṃ spārttalyñentane sporttolle.
A gap of about 18 akṣaras.

On the issuing of the ten commandments for a novice cf. . The offences covered in these commandments are the same in all versions, but in individual schools there are at times considerable differences in wording and in the order of commandments. These differences can be used to identify the affiliation of a particular text – and clearly show that this text here belongs to the Sarvāstivādin school. This school’s version, which used to be known in only one Chinese translation, presents the commandments in the following formal structure (cf. ): “Refraining from ... as long as you live is a commandment for a novice. Therefore as long as you live you shall refrain from... . Are you able to?” The candidate answers: “ I am able.” It is exactly this form of commandment that is found in this text.

Since, unfortunately, it is impossible to restore ·k·[ṣ·]·ts, its relation to Tumšuqese ba[cha] tsäṇakai moṣjāki (probably to be read thus acc. to D. Hitch in ) “a tiny worm (or) an ant” () and Skt. kuntapipīlakaḥ “worm or ant” (cf. ) remains unclear.
A gap of about 7 akṣaras at the end of the first fragment. Due to a knothole there is blank space between (nar)käṣälyñe and ṣanmīreṃtse.
ñreṣṣe peṅke 'piece of thread, fluff, lint'. peṅke seem to mean more or less 'part, small piece, section' (TA paṅk).
A gap of 6-7 akṣaras at the end of the first fragment.

anāyätte ketara ṣä(ñ waipecce) corresponds exactly to Tumšuqese handarā havya arorda tsātä “property of another that has not been given” (). For the restoration ketara ṣä(ñ waipecce) cf. also : a2 k(e)t rā ṣañ waipecce ṣärmasont palskalñe “a thought the cause of which is another’s property”. There is blank space amounting to one or two akṣaras between postaññe and rano.

line.tr: you (shall not) go (beyond such a point [= become guilty of such an offence]. If you accept this, say: I accept. 3. Refraining from sexual intercourse), [this is a] commandment for a novice. Therefore
you (shall not in your whole) live .... (practise sexual intercourse,) [not] (even) with one going (with a horizontal womb). Whatever [the circumstances], do not (go) beyond such
(a point [= become guilty of such an offence]! If you accept this) say: I accept. 4. Refraining from (telling a lie), [this is a] commandment for a novice. Therefore you shall
(not in your whole life, deliber)ately tell a lie, [not] even laughing [= as a joke]. (Whatever [the circumstances]), do not go beyond such a point! If (you accept this)
(say: I accept. 5. Refraining) from (drink)ing alcohol, (inebriating beverages [or] brandy), [this is a] commandment for (a novice). Therefore you shall (your whole life)
drink no alcohol,) inebriating beverage (?) [or] brandy, ([not] even with the tip of) [a blade of] Kuś(a-grass). Whatever [the circumstances], do not go beyond such a point! If
You mustn't cross this point on any account!
you accept this, say: (I accept. 6. Refraining from) [the use of] high [and] broad (beds), [this is a] commandment for a novice. Therefore your whole life

you (shall not use) high [and] broad] (beds. Whatever [the circumstances], do not go beyond such a point! If you accept this, say:) I accept. (7. Refraining from putting garlands, (odours of) flowers,

comments.comment: for Sanskrit see , for Sanskrit and Chinese and for Tumšuqese ;

The identification, ordering and extensive supplementation of the fragments of leaves 9-11 ( – ) is facilitated largely by parallel texts from Sanskrit Buddhist literature. Thus a1-2 is relatively closely matched by the Sanskrit text as restored from fragments of Turfan mss. by , and a2 – b3 may be compared with a Sanskrit text, also restored from Turfan fragments by . The former of the two is a section of text that can be found repeatedly in the Buddhist Sanskrit-tradition, such as CPS 16.16, 17.13, 22.15, 27f.22, NidSa 20.17, ŚPrSū 111, BimbSū 143. The Sanskrit text mentioned by deviates slightly from these as does the Chinese parallel having five commandments [pañcaśikṣāpadāni]; see . Beyond this a further parallel can be found, which surprisingly enough and except for a few minor deviations is remarkably close to the Tocharian text, and which therefore contributes greatly to supplementing our text here. It is a Tumšuqese Karmavācanā text (cf. ; for further reading) which from line 12-62 conforms almost verbatim to a1 – a3. Further important supplementations are owed to the TB fragments and [[PK NS 175]]. Certain deviations are caused by the fact that in the various versions occasionally different groups of persons are addressed. Thus the Sanskrit parts, the Tumšuqese text and contain formulas directed at lay followers (male, not female, as wrongly identified by ), while our text here contains directives for novices. The small fragment [[PK NS 175]] does not allow for any closer designation in this respect.

The text of the first five commandments of the Tocharian version could be largely completed with the help of the Skt. text supplied in , as well as – at least for commandments 1-3 – that of the Tumšuqese KaVā text. As for commandments 6-10, the Indic parallel versions (such as the Bhikṣukarmavākya, which belongs to the Mūlasarvāstivādin school) offer no more than mere lists of offences. For the Chinese Sarvāstivādin version cf. and . When one compares the Tocharian version with the Sanskrit text from the Bhikṣukarmavākya (p. 21) and the Pāli text from the Mahāvagga (I.56) the following picture emerges:
Toch. KaVā Bhu. Mahāvagga
1. (onolmeṃ kāwälyñe) 1. prāṇātipāta 1. pāṇātipāta
2. a(nāyätte ailyñe) 2. adattādāna 2. adinnādāna
3. (maithuṃ) 3. abrahmacarya 3. abrahmacariya
4. (waike welyñe) 4. mṛṣāvāda 4. musāvāda
5. m(ā)l(a trikelye śak)s(e yo)k(a)lyñe 5. surāmaireya-madyapramāda-sthāna 5. surāmeraya-majja-pamāda-ṭṭhāna
6. (ta)pp(r)e orotstse (leki) 8. uccaśayana-mahāśayana 9. uccāsayana-mahāsayana
7. pässakä(n)t(a) py(a)pyainä – – – ṣañem (yatäṣälyñe) 7. mālagandha-vilepana-varṇakadhāraṇa 8. mālagandha-vilepana-dhāraṇamaṇḍana-vibhūsaṇaṭṭhāna
8. (tsaipeṃ śarka ploriyaṃ yamaly)ñ(e) 6. nṛtya-gīta-vāditra 7. nacca-gīta-vāditavisūkadassana
9. (yasa ñkante) /// /// t(·)a ṣaṃñ eṅkaly(ñ)e 10. jātarūpa-rajata-pratigraha 10. jātarūpa-rajata-paṭiggahaṇa
10. (snai preke śwātsi) 9. akālabhojana 6. vikālabhojana

While commandments 1-4 – the supplementations of the Toch. text may be considered certain – do agree quite well in the various versions, commandments 5, 7, 8 (the Toch. text may be supplemented with certainty) and 9 display a number of differences in content, which render a persistent equation of the Tocharian sections with their respective counterparts in the Skt. and Pāli versions impossible.
The supplementations and commentaries follow .
According to : iv-v the ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

Of the original leaf 4 fragments remain: a smaller one from the left margin, about 3 cm wide and containing remnants of 3 and 2 lines respectively; another small fragment from beneath the string hole, about 2 cm wide and containing remnants of 1 and 2 lines respectively; a smaller fragment to the right of the string hole, connected up in two places, about 5 cm wide and containing remnants of 3 lines, with the verso partly abraded; and a fragment from the right side consisting of 2 pieces and about 9 cm wide.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2-3.
This leaf is in hand 1.
About 31 akṣaras are missing at the end of the first fragment.

restores to (maithunmeṃ narkäṣälyñe śa)nmireṃtse..., cf. b2 (pu)k maithunantwaṣ tmäkyok ñañ(ä)rkunt “[to you] who for this very reason has refrained from (an) sexual intercourse” (plural in Toch.), a somewhat freer rendering of Skt. uṣitabrahmacaryāya “[to thee,] who dwelt in the way of the brahmacārin” (the beginning of verse II.20 of Mātṛceṭa’s Varṇārhavarṇa-stotra. Text and translation .
ṣäkṣapāt for ṣikṣapāt.
A gap of about 9 akṣaras at the end of the first fragment, and a gap of about 11 at the end of the second. The reading śaulatsa of is wrong. ṣ·rette can also be read instead of ṣ·rente.

Without knowledge of its Skt. equivalent, n· ykusaimpa ṣesa, lit. “together with one [fem.] ... who has gone ...”, remains unclear. It is, however, the remainder of an element-by-element translation of Skt. tiryag-yoni-gatayā ... sārdham “with a [female] animal”, where n· translates Skt. yoni and ykusaimpa translates Skt. gatayā. tiryag-yoni-gatā literally means “one going with a horizontal womb”.
A gap of about 9 akṣaras at the end of the first fragment, and of about 7 at the end of the second.
te-yaknece for te-yäknece.
On the supplementation of waike (mā weṣä)l(l)e pos(ta)ṃññe r(a)no kerīyem(ane) cf. a 10 postäñe rano keriyemane waiyke mā weṣṣälle.

m(ā)l(a) – – – – ·s· is restored to m(ā)l(a trikelye śak)s(e) by . It is, however, problematic to compare this phrase to Skt. surā-maireya-madya- since in another ms. (: b2) the TB equivalent of the same Skt. phrase is mot māla trikelyesa śakse. According to this latter Hoernle passage mot has been equalled with Skt. surā- “brandy”, mālo* with Skt. maireya- (the name for an inebriating drink), and trikelle with Skt. madya- “inebriating drink, brandy” (: q.v.), while śakse has been disregarded. These equations, however, become questionable, if one takes into consideration that śikse (sic!) is attested as a translation of Skt. madya in [[SHT 1704]] b4 (cf. ), wherefore it is recommended here to regard mot “alcohol” as a cover term for alcoholic beverages, and , starting out from this passage here, to identify mālo* with Skt. surā-, trikelle with Skt. maireya- and śakse with Skt. madya-.
A gap of 7 akṣaras in the first fragment.

An alternative supplementation, of course, would be (tr)i(k)el(ye) (Obl.). In this case, then, it would be an impersonal gerundive construction with a dependent oblique case, which is repeatedly attested in this text, and to which cf. .
kātkat (likewise line a4 and a2), which belongs to kätk- “cross, walk over”, displays the initially accented full grade form kātk- that is to be expected in a singular active of Sub.V.
A gap of 7-8 akṣaras in the first fragment.

as(kwacentse ākesa) has been supplemented with b3 askwacentse ākesa based on the on Skt. kuśāgreṇa- "the sharp point of a blade of the Kuśa grass" in the Sanskrit parallel. The amendation of (y)o(ks)le is wrong (and probably a misprint).
A gap of about 8 akṣaras at the end of the first fragment, and about 7 at the end of the second.
A gap of about 27 akṣaras at the end of the first fragment.

line.tr: on your name (i.e. yourself) ([or] make-up, [this is a] commandment for a novice.) Therefore (your whole) life you shall (not put on garlands, (odours of) flowers, or make-up.)

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: Whatever [the circumstances], do not go beyond such (point [= become guilty of such an offence])! If you accept this, (say: I) accept.
(8.) Refraining from doing (dancing, singing [and] music), [this is a] commandment for a novice. Therefore your whole life you shall neither dance, (sing or make music) deliberately,
[nor] shall you go to see (dances), singing (?), music (?) [and] shows [lit. ornaments] (?). Whatever [the circumstances], (do not go) beyond such a (point! If)
(you accept this, say: I accept. 9.) Refraining from taking for yourself (valuables (?)), [this is a] command(ment) for a novice. (Therefore your whole life ...
... you shall not take). Whatever [the circumstances], (do not go beyond) such a point! (If you accept this, say:

(I accept. 10. Refr)aining (from eating at the wrong time), [this is a] commandment for a novice. Therefore your whole life you (shall not) deliberately (eat at the wrong time. Whatever [the circumstances])
(do not go beyond such a point!). If you accept this, say: I accept. You [now] became a novice. (Be successful in the) teaching[s] of the [Śākya-]lion
If you accept [this precept], say, «I accept it» 10.

([and] do not neglect) the difficult [to achieve] power of the virtues. || At first one shall venerate the feet [= bow down] [in front of the (the statue of) the Buddha]. After having venerated his feet [= bowed down] (you shall get up,)
(step forward (?) [and]) take (the kāṣāya) clothing. For (at the behest of) the Omniscient, (the Buddha), the being to be ordained shall (seize the kāṣāya clothing.)

comments.comment: for Sanskrit see , for Sanskrit and Chinese and for Tumšuqese ;

The identification, ordering and extensive supplementation of the fragments of leaves 9-11 ( – ) is facilitated largely by parallel texts from Sanskrit Buddhist literature. Thus a1-2 is relatively closely matched by the Sanskrit text as restored from fragments of Turfan mss. by , and a2 – b3 may be compared with a Sanskrit text, also restored from Turfan fragments by . The former of the two is a section of text that can be found repeatedly in the Buddhist Sanskrit-tradition, such as CPS 16.16, 17.13, 22.15, 27f.22, NidSa 20.17, ŚPrSū 111, BimbSū 143. The Sanskrit text mentioned by deviates slightly from these as does the Chinese parallel having five commandments [pañcaśikṣāpadāni]; see . Beyond this a further parallel can be found, which surprisingly enough and except for a few minor deviations is remarkably close to the Tocharian text, and which therefore contributes greatly to supplementing our text here. It is a Tumšuqese Karmavācanā text (cf. ; for further reading) which from line 12-62 conforms almost verbatim to a1 – a3. Further important supplementations are owed to the TB fragments and [[PK NS 175]]. Certain deviations are caused by the fact that in the various versions occasionally different groups of persons are addressed. Thus the Sanskrit parts, the Tumšuqese text and contain formulas directed at lay followers (male, not female, as wrongly identified by ), while our text here contains directives for novices. The small fragment [[PK NS 175]] does not allow for any closer designation in this respect.

The text of the first five commandments of the Tocharian version could be largely completed with the help of the Skt. text supplied in , as well as – at least for commandments 1-3 – that of the Tumšuqese KaVā text. As for commandments 6-10, the Indic parallel versions (such as the Bhikṣukarmavākya, which belongs to the Mūlasarvāstivādin school) offer no more than mere lists of offences. For the Chinese Sarvāstivādin version cf. and . When one compares the Tocharian version with the Sanskrit text from the Bhikṣukarmavākya (p. 21) and the Pāli text from the Mahāvagga (I.56) the following picture emerges:
Toch. KaVā Bhu. Mahāvagga
1. (onolmeṃ kāwälyñe) 1. prāṇātipāta 1. pāṇātipāta
2. a(nāyätte ailyñe) 2. adattādāna 2. adinnādāna
3. (maithuṃ) 3. abrahmacarya 3. abrahmacariya
4. (waike welyñe) 4. mṛṣāvāda 4. musāvāda
5. m(ā)l(a trikelye śak)s(e yo)k(a)lyñe 5. surāmaireya-madyapramāda-sthāna 5. surāmeraya-majja-pamāda-ṭṭhāna
6. (ta)pp(r)e orotstse (leki) 8. uccaśayana-mahāśayana 9. uccāsayana-mahāsayana
7. pässakä(n)t(a) py(a)pyainä – – – ṣañem (yatäṣälyñe) 7. mālagandha-vilepana-varṇakadhāraṇa 8. mālagandha-vilepana-dhāraṇamaṇḍana-vibhūsaṇaṭṭhāna
8. (tsaipeṃ śarka ploriyaṃ yamaly)ñ(e) 6. nṛtya-gīta-vāditra 7. nacca-gīta-vāditavisūkadassana
9. (yasa ñkante) /// /// t(·)a ṣaṃñ eṅkaly(ñ)e 10. jātarūpa-rajata-pratigraha 10. jātarūpa-rajata-paṭiggahaṇa
10. (snai preke śwātsi) 9. akālabhojana 6. vikālabhojana

While commandments 1-4 – the supplementations of the Toch. text may be considered certain – do agree quite well in the various versions, commandments 5, 7, 8 (the Toch. text may be supplemented with certainty) and 9 display a number of differences in content, which render a persistent equation of the Tocharian sections with their respective counterparts in the Skt. and Pāli versions impossible.
The supplementations and commentaries follow .
According to : iv-v the ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

Of this leaf 3 fragments are left: a small fragment top left from the string hole, about 1 cm wide and containing remnants of a single line ( (cf. ), inserted at the beginning of lines a 1 and b 5 below); a large fragment to the right of the string hole, about 13 cm wide and consisting of 3 pieces. Connecting to the latter on the top right with only a few milimetres between them is a small fragment, about 3.5 cm wide, consisting of 2 pieces and containing remnants of 3 lines. The leaf number is not preserved.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2-3.
The first fragment is in hand 1, the rest is in hand 2.
On ṣañem (= ṣañ ñem) for ṣañ āñm cf. .
There is a gap of about 7-8 akṣaras at the beginning of this line. At the end of the inserted fragment there is one of about 8, and about 15 akṣaras are missing to the end of this line.
ṣañem (for ṣañ ñem) from is supplemented here according to ().
warpatär for warpatar.
About 11 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line, and around 6 to the end of it.
narkäṣälyñe sic!
About 9 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 7 to the end of it.
ṣanmīretse for ṣanmīrentse.

tsaipeṃ śarka ploriyaṃ yetweṃ lkātsi yale based on the Sanskrit parallel (see above) the following correspondence could be established : Skt. nṛtya- "dance", : Skt. gīta- "singing, song, poem", : Skt. vādita- "instrumental music". According to : q.v. ploriyo* is an instrument, according to . specifically a wind instrument (possibly a flute). The concrete meaning "instrument" seemingly found in other passages and the more abstract meaning "instrumental music" in the given context can easily be reconciled if Tocharian ploriyo* and BHS vādita- had the same range of meaning as Classical Skt. vāditra-, namely, "musical instrument; instrumental music" (-c). Similarly, it seems that śarka not only means "lute" (.), but in the present context also more generally refers to "song". The other possibility is that śarka and ploriyo together refer to - lute and flute - music as partes pro toto; cf. b1, and a3 where we also have a collocation of śarka and ploriyo. and 127 interprets "ornament, decoration" as equivalent of Pāli visūka- "show" (see above). In this case the meaning of yetwe (which also corresponds to Skt. anuvyañjana- "minor mark, characteristic") could be more generally understood as "characterisation", in the context of the commandment thus with the reading of "act of characterisation", i.e. "show, performance".
About 11 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 6 to the end of it.
(na)rkaṣalyñe sic!
About 13 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 8 to the end of it.
ṣanmīretse for ṣanmīrentse.
About 16 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 7 to the end of it.
About 9 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 8 to the end of it.
ṣanmīretse for ṣanmīrentse.
enäṣälyñene for enäṣṣälñene.
About 8 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 3 to the end of it.
(ṣe)c(a)keṃts[e]: the fact that the Tocharian text lacks the equivalent of Skt. śākya-, i.e. śakkeññepi would seem to be a mere slip on the part of the scribe.
wewinaṣormeṃ for wewinaṣṣormeṃ.

paiyne wināsk- lit. “to revere the feet”, just like Skt. pādau śirasā vand- and Pāli pāde sirasā vand-, means “to bow down at someone’s feet”. Cf. also a5, where paiyne wināṣṣälle corresponds to the Skt. pādā śirasā vanditavyāḥ of the Bhikṣuṇī-Vinaya (Mā-L), § 38.
About 9 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 3 to the end of it. /// pp·s is another possible reading.
About 5 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line, and there is a gap of about 6 akṣaras after poyśi. w(a)saṃtpāt: the reading w(a)saṃnpāt as in or w(a)saṃpāt as in is unlikely.
(was)ts(i) eṅ(kaṣäle) from is supplemented here according to (). onolmetse for onolmentse.

line.tr: (Why so? Because, since the time of the) Buddha (Vipa)śyin (all beings that go from the house) put on the (kāṣāya) garb. Silk clothes [are?] calling forth the kleśas, ...

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: ... (resembling(?) the sand(?) in the river) Gaṅgā [i.e. an unimaginably huge number] ... (no garb) being (in the saṃsāra without beginning) has been left, [neither] divine [nor] human, that you have not worn. Among the humans ...
... you donned just (these) splendid clothes [and] decorated yourself with royal ornaments. When you (were reborn) among the gods
you donned excellent (silken(?) div)ine clothes. Having donned silken clothes, in someone (you have) thus (raised) passion, hate [and] discord ...
(Among the asuras) you donned only clothes bringing [i.e. which brought] fear to the beings. Like (a warrior) fighting a battle
... (thus, [reborn] among the pretas), when you were attached to wrong views [i.e. heresy = mithyādṛṣṭi], you befouled your body very much with the dust(?) of excrements(?) [and] ...
... [you] were naked (?), donning the dust(?) (of excrements(?)). Just so, when you were [re]born in the hells, (you were) squeezed [between] sheets of red-hot iron.
(When) you were [re]born (among animals) [as] garb you donned, in many ways, fur(?), plumage(?) [and] scales(?) [and] therefore (you were hunted(?)) by the (creatures)

(on the four) continents. Having donned (such) clothes you suffered intolerable sufferings in the beginning-less saṃsāra. (When (?) you now have donned) the (kāṣāya) garb, (then(?)) at last (you) become free from sorrow. Like the householders (among(?) the) humans ...

comments.comment: The supplementations and commentaries follow .
According to : iv-v the ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.
Probably also accommodates fragment , cf. (on p. 34 read “gehört vielleicht zu Blatt (12)” instead of “(13)”).
Large fragment from the centre of the leaf, to the right of the string hole, consisting of 5 pieces and about 20 cm wide. Damages similar to . The leaf number is not preserved.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2-3.
This leaf is in hand 2.
yäskeṃträ is the 3rdPl.Prs.Mid. of wäs- 'to put on, to don something', the present stem of which is attested also as the Imp. yäṣṣitär.
tono-wäsanma (tonoṃ-wäsanma in line a4): tono 'silk' is a loan word from Iranian, cf. Khotanese thauna- 'cloth, silk'. Uy. ton “dress” is also derived from thauna- ().
About 16 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 2 to the end of it. A reading tw· seems to be more in accordance with the still recognisable remains than a reading kw·.
The gap at the beginning may have contained (vipa)śyi pañ[i]kt(e) from b4 according to ).
ñikcyīye for ñäkciye.
About 13 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and 2 akṣaras are missing to the end of this line.
The gap at the beginning of this line may have contained rmeṃ gāṅ·e from b5 according to ).
pärsantaṃṣe 'splendid, brilliant, bright'.
ṣaññ añmä yātatai you decorated yourself, from the root yät- ‘decorate’.
About 10 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 3 to the end of it.
Supplementation to tonak is possible.
wasātai sic! for wäsātai.
eṃkäl for eṅkäl.
About 8 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 1-2 to the end of it.
weta wata: perhaps to be supplemented to wata(lyñe), Abstr. II, probably from wät- ‘fight’.
About 8-9 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 7 to the end of it.

m[e]·n·[ṣ]p·ltsa is unclear. If [ṣ]p(e)ltsa can be isolated – cf. line b2, where one might perhaps supplement to (ṣ)[p](e)l – ṣpel could be suggested to mean something along the lines of ‘powder, dust’ rather than ‘(little) ball, bead(let), globule’ as in : q.v.
kariṣ is most likely a loan from Skt. karīṣa ‘dirt, excrement’.
About 8-9 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 7 to the end of it.
me·n·ṣp·ltsa: separation into individual words uncertain.
peruwartse is only attested here and perhaps means ‘naked(?)’.
pälkoṣ-eñcuwañeṃ ‘[ones] consisting of glowing iron’.

The likely supplementation to pa[t]r·[kä](n)[t](a) implies that this is the plural of an alternans noun with masculine agreement, which is unexpected. However, while attestations of this kind do mostly appear in poetic texts, they are also to be identified with certainty in prose texts, albeit not frequently (on this cf. .). In case pa[t]r·[k] is borrowed from Skt. pattraka, it may have meant something like ‘[metal] sheet, thin board’, which would fit the current context nicely. A connection to pa[t]rī /// in b7 (reading suggested by ) does seem, however, impossible since pa[t]r·[kä](n)[t](a) is a noun, while pa[t]rī ///, judging from the Skt. model, must be adjectival.
tw·ṅ[k](ä) /// belongs with the root twāṅk- ‘squeezed in’ (, 129) or ‘wear, don’ (cf. ). Supplementation uncertain.
About 7-8 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 2 to the end of it.

ausa is the Obl.Sg. of the PPt. of the root wäs- ‘to wear, don’, meaning approximately ‘clothing, garb’. A Loc. of this verbal noun might be present in a 2, where has considered supplementing to (au)sane.

aṣitaṃ pār pitsamonta (probably to be separated thus, but pārpi tsamonta is another possibility) must refer to the three main types of animals’ hides: fur, plumage and scales. aṣitaṃ ‘fur(?)’, only attested here, so far has remained without any connection, within Tocharian or elsewhere. It is tempting to regard pār ‘plumage(?)’, equally a hapax legomenon, as a singular (used as collective noun) of parwa 'feathers', but the attested plural forms ( b3 paruwa, a 4 [p]arwa, b1 sn(ai) parwā and Loc. parwāne in a5) seem to warrant a singular form *par (thus .1) rather than pār. pitsamonta ‘scales(?)’ might be identical with pit-tsamonta preserved in a3, where, however, the context is unfortunately largely destroyed, and which explains as pit-tsamonta ‘gallstones’ (connected to tsamo ‘excrescence, tumour’).
About 7 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 2 to the end of it.
pitsamonta: separation into individual words uncertain.
The gap between these lines may have contained (śtwā)r(a) dv(i)p(anma) from a1 according to ).

[ai]rpittona läklenta wärpātai, lit. ‘you received unenjoyable sufferings’: the privative airpitte (usually written airpätte) does not belong with the root yärp- ‘observe, take care’ (pace , § 33, who translate as ‘unheeded’), but rather with the root wärp- ‘enjoy; receive, feel’ and thus means ‘unenjoyable, intolerable’.

About 11-12 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 3 to the end of it. The word initial ai of airpittona is not written with the vowel sign for ai, as is usually the case, but as a plus a superscript diacritic for ai.
– ·e kaṣār: the still recognizable remains would argue against supplementing to (ent)e; (tan)e is a much more likely alternative.
The gap between these lines may have contained kaṣār-wa(sts)i from a2 according to ).
About 15 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line and about 2 to the end of it. Instead of w-, the beginning of the second word in this line could also be read as au-.

prose.s:
... has traded for himself the kāṣāya garb.
kaṣār wassi myāskate
The Buddha .... commanded [his] students to don the kāṣāya [garb]. pañikte ñ· ak(a)lkälyets yātka te kaṣār wastsi

Therefore you shall now behave according to the way [and] precept of the Buddha-teachers, alike (to the sand in the river Gaṅgā). tane ñake g·
eneśle pañikte käṣṣintaṃts yaknene watk(ä)ṣälyñene spo(rto)le star-c
And just this now do in your mind: te ka ṣpä ñake palskone pyāmtsar

“How (do) I (seize) this k(āṣāya garb)? mäkte ce ·k· (eṅka)
skemar

May I be diligent in that which is suitable for the kāṣāya garb, [i.e.] in the virtues of munificence [dāna], (moral conduct [śīla], wis)dom [prajña], patience [kṣānti], energy [vīrya], [and] meditation [dhyāna]! kUse cwi kaṣār wä(ss)itse ayāto āyo(r) (ai)ś(a)mñe kälṣamñe tsirauwñe ompalskoñe (kre)
ntaunane tune ñiś spelkesu tāko(ymä)
(In this way you shall seize the kā)ṣāya garb. (ka)ṣār wa(ssi) ||
I here now order you to be asked: tane ñake watkäskau-c wetsi
[Is] this your garb? (Say: [yes it is] mine). tañ se wass(i)

Pay heed to this, venerable one!
aiśai te pyāmtsar
I, (N.N., seize this saṃghāṭī garb) which is cut [and] made [as] saṃghāṭī. śaulasū ñiś (eṅkaske)mar kärstoṣ saṃghāṭi pepyutkoṣ

[Thus] a second [and] (a third time) [it must] be spoken. wate
weṣäle ||
[These words are to be repeated in Skt.]: [Is] this your garb? tavedaṃ cīvaraṃ
Say: po(ñ)
([Yes, it is] mine. Pay heed to this, venerable one! I), N.N. (seize) this saṃghāṭī garb, which is cut [as] saṃghāṭī. (i)tthaṃnāma idaṃ cīvara saṃghāṭim adhi(tiṣṭhāmi)
cchinna saṃghāṭi
Thus a second [and] (a third time). evaṃ dvir api
[Is ] (this) your (garb? Say: [Yes, it is] mine). tañ s(e)
Pay heed to this, venerable one! aiśai te pyāmtsar • śaulasu

I, N.N. seize (this) uttarāsaṅga garb, [made] from seven parts of (two) and a half (maṇḍalas) [each]. ñiś te ñem(tsa)
uttarāsāṅkä eṅkaske(ma)r ṣuktañce ywārtsa c·
This [must be] said three [times]. te tarya weṣäle ||
[These words must be repeated in Skt.]: tavedaṃ civ(ara)ṃ
[Is] this your garb? (p)o(ñ)
(Say: [Yes, it is] mine). (mama)

Pay heed to this, venerable one! (sa)
manvāharāṣmaṃ

I , N.N., seize this uttarāsaṅga (garb), which (is made and prepared) from seven parts of two and a half maṇḍalas [each]. aham itthaṃnāma idaṃ (cīva)ra(ṃ) uttarās(a)ṅkäm adhitiṣthāmi saptakaṃ kṛtvā (tṛ)
tīyārdhātimaṇḍalaṃ
Thus a second [and] (a third time). evaṃ dvi(r)·
[Is] this (your) garb? s(e) wassi
Say: poñ
[Yes, it is] mine. ce ñi
Pay heed to this, vener(able one! I, N.N., ) aiśai te pyāmtsar śau(lasu)

comments.comment: The supplementations and commentaries follow .
TB: tañ se wass(i) – – – (ñi) aiśai te pyāmtsar śaulasū ñiś (te-ñemtsa ce wassi saṃghāṭi eṅkaske)mar kärstoṣ saṃghāṭi pepyutkoṣ (the TB version ends here)
Skt.: tav=edaṃ cīvaraṃ ... (mama samanvāhar=āyuṣmām aham i)tthaṃnāma idaṃ cīvara(ṃ) saṃghāṭim adhi(tiṣṭhāmi) cchinna(ṃ) saṃghāṭi(ṃ) (the Skt. version ends here)
Mainz 629: tav=edaṃ civara(ṃ) mama sama(nvāhar=ācārya aham kṣemasa idaṃ) civaraṃ saṃghādhim adhitiṣṭhāmi cchinnaṃ saṃghāṭiṃ .... (kṛtaṃ niṣṭhitaṃ) ...

The end of this set phrase is totally different in the three versions. The TB text ends with pepyutkoṣ, which does not have any equivalent in the Skt. version, but is represented in Mainz 629 by niṣṭhitaṃ at the end of the phrase (the supplementation is certain, based on the end of the two following phrases). The rendition of Skt. niṣṭhita as TB pepyutku is proven by TA. In a2 the form papyätku can be found, which corresponds to niṣṭhita in the Skt. Parallel (Naiḥsargika-pātayantika-dharma I). On the appearance and fabrication of the three types of monks’ habits saṃghāṭī, uttarāsaṅga and antarvāsa see .
According to : iv-v this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

From this leaf there are 2 large fragments: the left side around the string hole, consisting of 5 pieces and about 12 cm wide; and a large fragment from the centre of the leaf at a distance of about 1 cm from the other, consisting of 3 pieces and about 10-11 cm wide.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2-3.
This leaf is in hand 2.
pañikte for pañäkte.
ak(a)lkälyets must be supplemented and corrected to ak(a)lṣälye(ṃ)ts.
On the basis of b1 and 1, the gap at the end of this line must be supplemented to [g](āṅc ckene warañcämpa) eneśle.
pañikte for pañäkte; watkäṣälyñene for watkäṣṣälñene; sportole for sporttolle.
tsirauwñe for tsirauñe; ompalskoñe for ompalskoññe.
spelkesu for speltkessu.

Supplemented to (papāṣṣorñe ai)ś(a)mñe etc. This line contains the 6 pāramitās (“supreme virtues”) in Tocharian translation: āyo(r) = Skt. dāna, (papāṣṣorñe) = Skt. śīla, (ai)ś(a)mñe = Skt. prajñā, kälṣamñe = Skt. kṣānti, tsirauwñe = Skt. vīrya and ompalsk[o]ñ[e] = Skt. dhyāna.
spelkesu for speltkessu; tākoymä for tākoym; wetsi for wentsi; wassi for wastsi.

These lines contain the TB translation of the Skt. text following in lines b1-2. A parallel text, corresponding relatively closely to this text here, was found in a Skt.-Uy. Karmavācanā fragment from the Staatsbibliothek Preussischer Kulturbesitz in Berlin (Berlin State Library), shelf mark Mainz 629 (recto and verso).
śaulasū for śaulassu.
weṣäle for weṣṣälle.
cīvara must be supplemented and corrected to cīvaraṃ.
śaulasu for śaulassu.
According to the Tocharian translation (cf. a 5 kärstoṣ saṃghāṭi), cchinna saṃghāṭi must be corrected to cchinnaṃ saṃghāṭiṃ or cchinnaṃ saṃghāṭīṃ.

Again the TB translation precedes the Skt. model (lines b3-b5). Here, too, the final parts deviate from each other in the three versions. In the TB version after eṅkaske (ma)r (= Skt. adhitiṣṭhāmi) it says: ṣuktañce ywārtsa – – – – – – c·, to which corresponds saptakaṃ kṛtvā – – – – – (tṛ)tīyārdhātimaṇḍalaṃ in the Skt. model and (saptakaṃ kṛtvā) – – – (tṛtīyār)dhā(ti)maṇḍalaṃ kṛtaṃ niṣṭhitaṃ pāribhogikaṃ in Mainz 629, where (tṛtīyār)[dhā](ti)maṇḍalaṃ is probably, and niṣṭhitaṃ is certainly, to be corrected thus.
weṣäle for weṣṣälle.
uttarāsaṅkäm sic! for uttarāsaṅgam.
wassi for wastsi; śaulasu for śaulassu.

The TB translation in this line down to a1 again precedes the Skt. model ( a1-2). The final parts of the individual versions – after eṅkaskemar (= Skt. adhitiṣṭhāmi) are as follows: TB (wlaṃśkeṃ antarvā)s, Skt. śla(kṣ)ṇ(o a)ntarvāso vā and Mainz 629 ślakṣṇam antarvāsaṃ kṛtaṃ niṣṭhitaṃ pāribho(gikaṃ). śla(kṣ)ṇ(o a)ntarvāso, compared to the previous entirely corresponding two phrases as well as to Mainz 629, should probably be corrected to read śla(kṣ)ṇ(am a)ntarvāsaṃ. In this case the TB equivalent must be the above stated (wlaṃśkeṃ antarvā)s. The vā at the end of the Skt. text remains unclear.

mama samanvaharāyuṣmāṃ aha

line.tr: (seize this antarvāsa garb, a soft antarvā)sa. (This [must be] spoken) three (times). [These words must be repeated in Skt.]: [Is] this (your) garb? Say: [Yes, it is] mine. Pay heed to this, venerable one! I,

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: (N.N.), seize (this) antarvāsa (garb), (a) so(ft) antarvāsa. Thus a second [and] a third time. Thus, too, (you shall) seize the eating bowl.
The Omniscient, the Buddha, has commanded the being to be ordained to seize the eating bowl since (it(?) leads (?) to(?)) immeasurably moral conduct [śīla].
(Because(?),) for the purity of living [your] life [ājīvapāriśuddhu], [which is] conductive to moral conduct, you shall seize the eating bowl. Just as now [for you]
([there is] no way of living [your] life [ājīva] [left] among the householders(?)) – ignoble(?) ways of living life are fighting wars(?), ploughing(?), trade [krayavikraya], the crafts,
for/with/to x-ing [and] so on, whatever [other] ways of living life [there are] – just so [there is] (n)o [eating bowl] existing in the beginning-less saṃsāra
(left), from which you have (not) eaten. When you (were) born among the gods, (from) divine golden, beryl, silver [and] crystal vessels
(heavenly(?)) food you were eating. In hell, then, you were eating red-hot iron balls, [and] molten copper
(you were drinking). Of the heretics, (of which) there are ... (96) [different] ways of going from the house, some consume the alms food from the palm[s] of their hand[s], others (from) human
(brainpan[s]) .... (All these) suchlike ways of living life are completely wrong [and] erroneous, since they lead to [new re]births [and]

comments.comment: The supplementation and commentaries follow .
According to : iv-v the ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

From this leaf 2 large fragments are preserved: one to the right of the string hole, about 6 cm wide; and another fragment from the right side at a distance of about 1 cm from the other, consisting of 5 pieces and about 16 cm wide. The recto is discoloured to a blackish hue rendering the script almost illegible. The leaf number is not preserved.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2-3.
This leaf is in hand 2.
weṣäle for weṣṣälle.
samanvaharāyuṣmāṃ: sic! and should be corrected to samanvāharāyuṣmāṃ.
About 14 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line.
The beginning of the line can probably be supplemented with (wlaṃśkeṃ antarvā)s; cf. , and commentary to : a1.
eṅkaṣalya for eṅkaṣälya.

ślakṣṇa: it is unclear what is meant by this - perhaps a piece of clothing not made from smaller pieces, but cut from a single cloth? ślakṣṇam antarvāsaṃ is also to be found in Mainz 629, a Skt.-Uy. Karmavācanā text (cf. .), which, however, does not contribute to an explanation of ślakṣṇa.
About 9 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line.
wasatpāt for wasaṃtpāt; yamaṣälyepi for yamaṣṣälyepi; onolmetse for onolmentse; pañikte for pañäkte; eṅtsi for eṅktsi; yarmä for yarm; papāṣorñe for papāṣṣorñe.
About 7 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line.
papāṣorñetse for papāṣṣorñentse; ayātośca for ayātośco for ayātośc; śailñentse for śailyñentse; astarñeśc for astaräññeś; eṅkaṣalya for eṅkaṣälya; star-ca for star-c.
ayātośc(a) (for ayātośc(ä)) is a postposition taking the genitive and meaning 'for (the benefit of)' (cf. a4).
starca sic! for starcä (= starc).
About 8 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line.
śailyñenta for śailñenta; yamalyñe for yamalñe.
weta watal(yñe) is a figura etymologica; watal(yñe) is an Abstr. II of wät- ‘fight’. Cf. a5 wata /// and commentary.
The form p·to cannot be supplemented with any certainty. The word would appear to be the TB equivalent of TA pate 'agriculture, ploughing'.
About 8 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line.
The first word in this line may perhaps be read as and supplemented to [y](a)kte - hardly [s·]kte and certainly not (mä)kte! The ending of the last word in this line is uncertain.
śailyñenta for śailñenta; sportomane for sporttomane.
About 9 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line.
ñikciyana for ñäkciyana; ysāṣana for ysāṣṣana; ñkäñcana for ñkañcana; mastarkaläṣana for mastarkaläṣṣana; bhajanta for bhājanta.
mastarkaläṣe is an adjectival derivation of so far unattested *mastarkal ‘rock crystal’.
About 9 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line.
The last word in this line should probably be supplemented to bha(jānäntane) or bha(jāntane) - or perhaps even be corrected to bhā(jantane)?
nraiyne for nraine; krepastaṃ for krepasteṃ; mloṣä for mloṣ.

krepastaṃ sic! To be corrected to krepasteṃ, cf. b 5 iñcuwaññeṃ krepaste(ntsa). krepaste = ‘ball, globe, Skt. guḍā’. Further attestations: krepaste /// in b5 (= Skt. guḍābhiḥ) and krepäste /// in [[THT 3598]] b6.
śawāsta the finite Pt. of the root śu is always formed from the stem śāwā in this ms.
mloṣä from *mlau ‘molten’, PPt. of the root mäl-, ca. ‘be squashed, melt (?)’, which is also etymologically related to German schmelzen ‘melt’ (IE *(s)mel-d-).
pilke ‘copper, Skt. tāmra’.
About 9 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line.
pärnañets for pärnāññeṃts;lalyñe for lalñe; ālīne for ālyine; warpananträ for wärpanantär.
pärnañets sic! for pärnāñets.
About 8 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line.
śailyñenta for śailñenta.
About 12 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line.

pañikte prekesa kuśalamūläci ono(lm)ī ·eṃ /// /// r·ṇāgamtsa : wasanpāt yamaṣṣere kete tuśca kuślamulänta

line.tr: [they] increase the [stay in the] saṃsāra. The Omniscient, the Buddha, (ate [his] alms food from a bowl(?)). From bowls(?) (also) the earlier Buddhas ate alms food, [and] from a bowl(?),

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: the eating bowl, the [Buddhas] to arise later [will eat their alms food]. ... The Buddha himself seized the eating bowl [and] just this [he] commanded [his] pupils [to do].
Therefore (you shall) seize the eating bowl. Thus you shall earn [your] living: If with little effort you may acquire alms food to eat, [you shall] consume [it]; [if,]

however, [you do] not acquire [it in this way], you shall beg for [it] (with) this eating bowl. But you shall not, for the sake of food, let fade away [this way of] earning [your] livelihood. For (in order to(?)) do this
(the monk?) seizes the eating bowl. And this now do in your mind: Just like the eating bowl seizes the essence [rasa], just so I
wish (to seize the bowl of) moral conduct [and] be a bowl [vessel] of virtues! This (I) now ask (you): [Is] this your eating bowl? Say: [Yes, it is] mine. Pay heed to this, venerable one! I,

N.N., seize this excellent eating bowl, an eating bowl undamaged, a vessel for ṛṣis. This [must] be said thrice. [These words must be repeated in Skt.]: [Is] this your eating bowl? Say: [Yes, it is] mine. Pay heed to this, venerable one!
I, N.N., seize this excellent eating bowl, an eating bowl undamaged, a vessel for ṛṣis. Thus a second [and] a third time. Now you shall ask for a teacher [upādhyāya].
Thus also the being to be ordained, (at the) bidding of the Omniscient, the Buddha, shall ask for a teacher. Why this? Because

at the time of the Buddha, the beings which were equipped with the roots of good [kuśalamūlāni] (went from the house) [and] were ordained (without a teacher), [only] (by the threefold) taking (of refuge). These that had therefore gathered the roots of good

comments.comment: The supplementation and commentaries follow .
TB: tañ sā pātro ... ñi aiśai te pyāmtsar śaulasu ñiś (te)-ñemts(a) tā pātrai prucamñai eṅkaskemar solmīyai pātrai rṣākäññe bhajaṃ
Skt.: tav=edaṃ pātraṃ ... mama samanvāhar=āyuṣmā(ṃ) aham itthaṃnāma idaṃ pātraṃ pāribhogikam adhitiṣṭhā(mi) paripūrṇaṃ pātraṃ ṛṣibhājanam
According to iv-v the ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.
From this leaf the full width is preserved, consisting of 10 pieces. To the right of the string hole lines a1-2 are missing over a stretch of about 7 and 4 cm respectively.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 4
The leaf is in hand 2.
pañikte for pañäkte; nauṣañi for nauṣaññi; pañikti for pañäkti; piṃtwāt for pintwāt.
lykace (Obl.Sg.; lykacenne Loc.Pl.), name for a vessel, perhaps ‘bowl (?), cup(?)’.
The gap contains about 8 akṣaras.
lykacenne should be read thus rather than lyka cenne.
ompostaṃ for ompostäṃ; warpananträ for wärpanantär; pañikte for pañäkte; eṃksate for eṅksate; akalyṣalyeṃts for akalṣälyeṃts.
warpananträ sic! for wärpananträ.
eṅkaṣalya for eṅkaṣälya; śawaṣäle for śawaṣṣälle; star-cä for star-c; piṃtwātä for pintwāt; källātä for källāt; wärpanale for wärpanalle.
källātä for källāt; yaskaṣṣäle for yaskaṣṣälle; star-cä for star-c; śaiyñe for śailñe; ṣparkäṣäle for ṣpärkaṣṣälle; star-cä for star-c.
The last word in this line must be a case form of the abstract noun yamalyñe, most likely the perlative yamalyñesa (as supplemented).
papāṣorñe for papāṣṣorñe.
tākoymä for tākoym; krentaunaṃts for krentaunats; tākymä for tākoym; śaulasu for śaulassu.
The TB translation precedes the text of the Skt. model (lines b2-3). The two versions are conforming exactly:
weṣäle for weṣṣälle; prucamñai for pruccamñai; solmīyai for solmiyai.
prucamñaim Obl.Sg.Fem. of pruccamo ‘excellent’ (cf. b2). This ms. so far contains the only attestations of TB forms of the adj. pruccamo (= TA pruccamo).
adhitiṣṭhā is to be corrected to adhitiṣṭhāmi.
On ñake upādhyāye yaskaṣale cf. Upasampadājñaptiḥ, p.8, 11 tataḥ paścād upādhyāyo yācitavyaḥ.

yaskaṣale for yaskaṣṣälle; star-caṃ for star-cä for star-c; pañikte for pañäkte; käṣṣitse for käṣṣintse; yaitkaursa for yaitkorsa; onolmetse for onolmentse; yaskaṣäle for yaskaṣṣälle; kātsi for kāttsi.
starcaṃ sic! Should be corrected to starcä (for starc). yaitkaursa sic! for yaitkorsa.
pañikte for pañäkte ; onolmī for onolmi; wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt; kuślamulänta for kuśalamūlänta.
yamaṣṣere sic! Scribal error for yamaṣṣare. tuśca sic! for tuścä (= tuśc). r·ṇāgamtsa most likely to be corrected and supplemented to (triśa)r(a)ṇagamtsa. kuś\lamulänta sic! for kuśalamulänta.
The gap contains about 8 akṣaras.

prose.s:
... were bound.
mälkauwa ṣeyeṃ
They (were) releas(ed.) cai pästä tsä(lpiyenträ) ///
(The others, however, who) went from the house (without a teach)er, [they] were without refuge [anātha]. /// (upādh)yāyeṃ ostameṃ lnaṣyeṃ anāsä (mä)skiyenträ
They rec(eived) neither proclamation [nor] instruction, welyñe enäṣälyñe mā kä(lpāṣyeṃ)

nor service in sickness.
tekine spaktaṃ mā kälpāṣyeṃ
The T(īrthikas) reproached: t(irthi) nakṣ(i)y(e)nträ
Without refuge (are) the śākya-monks! anās (ske)nt(e) śakeñi ṣamāni

To protect from this reproach the Buddha has appointed the u(pādhyāya). ce n(ā)k(i) pāssitse pelkiñ päñikte u(pādhyāyeṃ) (yā)
tka

Just like, in householdership, father [and] (mo)ther are protection [and] refuge, (keep [one] away) from evil [and] attach [one] to the (good), comparable to this the Upādhyāya [is] protection [and] re(fuge) in the law of the (Bud)dha, (keeps [one] away) from evil [and] (attaches one to the good). mäkte kattakäñene pācer (mā)cer mäsket(rä) (s)ai(m) (y)olo(m)eṃ (a)l(asträ) (ka)r(ts)ene rittaṣä(ṃ) tumpa tasem(ane) (pañi)
ktäñe peleknene upadhyāye saim (pä)rma(ṅk) y(o)lomeṃ (ritta)ṣṣ(äṃ)

Whatever deprivation may be [in store] for you here, (he does) you (service) in sickness with (food, drink,) a bed, remedies, and so on. kUse ṅke tañ tane meṅki tā(ka)ṃ
leki sātkesa warñai tekine ṅke sp(aktāṃ) (yamaṣäṃ)ñ-c

Thus .... whatever your desire may be, (he removes(?) the doubts that have risen in you [such as]) compunction about the sūtra, (vinaya, abhdharma,) [the existence(?) as] an āraṇyaka [monk]. and so on. tais(a) kUse ṅke kulypele tākaṃñ-ca sū(t)rä (abhidhā)
rm(ä) arāñeṣṣe palskalyñesa wa(r)ñ(ai) ///

(....) (If he himself) should not be able [to do so], (he will grant(?)) you that (through(?)) another. /// ·t· m(ā) c(ä)mp(a)mo tākaṃ tu ṅke ale(k) (yamaṣäṃ)
cä
You, however, (shall love) the upādhyāya like father [and] mother. tañ no mäkte mātar pātarne tai(sa) (upā)dhyāyenne

(As) one who has gained honour, as such you shall (honour the upādhyāya). l· perne kälpoṣne taisa u(pādhyāyenne)
yamaṣäle star-ca
[As(?)] with one who has gained honour, so(?) (with a) upā(dhyāya) ..... perne kälpoṣne te upa(dhyāyenn)e y·

(When the upā)dhyāya speaks to you [or] isntructs (you), [you] shall behave (in this way): ·e (upā)dhyāye weñ-co enasta(r-c)
spartole

A commandment from the upādhyāya [you shall] receive [with] hands folded together, speech [and] instruction from the upādhyāya [you shall receive] with [an inclination of] the head. upadhyāyetse pe(lai)kneṣṣe watkäṣ(ä)lyñ(e) (a)ñcāl(i) up(ā)dhyāyetse welyñe enäṣälyñe tarnene wärpana(le)

(Thus) [you] shall be (tire)less in the service of the upādhyāya.
upādhyāyetse spaktaṃnne a(lālä)te mäs(k)ele
The words, that I now give you to say, these say loudly: ce ñ(ak)e (re)kauna weñau-c wentsi tu we(k)ts(e) poñ
Pay heed to this, venerable one! aiśai te pyāmtsar śaulasū
I, (N.N.,) ñ(i)ś

line.tr: Wie Vater [und] Mutter ... vom Bösen (fernhalten) [und] an das (Gute) binden, ...
Like father [and] mother ... (keep [one] away) from evil [and] attach [one] to the (good), ...
Whatever need you may have here, in case of illness he serves you with (food, drink), bed, medicine, etc. (cf 49, 82)
Whatever you desire, he will (remove your doubts) like thoughts about the sūtra, (vinaya [and] abhidharma), or about the Āraṇya monk etc. (cf 49, 82)
If he is not able [to do it] (himself), then he will (let) somebody else (do it) for you. (cf 49, 82)
If the upādhyāya speaks to you or instructs you, you are to behave in this way. (cf 50, 82)
The words which I now tell you to say, say that aloud! (cf 50, 83)
Pay attention, reverend! I (of this name) ask you [to be] my upādhyāya. [Please] be, reverend, my upādhyāya! With you, reverend, as upādhyāya I will be ordained.

comments.comment: The supplementation and commentaries follow .
TB: aiśai te pyāmtsar śaulasū ñ(i)ś (te-ñemtsa) ci śaulasontä upādhyāyeṃ yaskaske(mar t)w(e śaulasu ñi upādhyāye ptā)k(a) ci śaulasotsa upadhyāyetsa ñiś wasanpāt yāmu
Skt.: samanvāhara bhadanta aham evaṃnāmā bhadantaṃ upādhyāyaṃ yāce bhadanto me upādhyāyo bhavatu bhadantena upādhyāyena upasaṃpatsye |
According to iv-v the ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

From this leaf 4 fragments are preserved: one from the left side reaching up to the string hole, about 7-8 cm wide; to the right of the string hole and connecting to the first a smaller fragment from the centre of the leaf, 4 cm wide and containing remnants of 3 lines; a small fragment from the centre of the leaf, about 2 cm wide and containing remnants of 2 lines; and a large fragment from the right side, consisting of 4 pieces, about 13 cm wide and connecting to the second fragment at a distance of about 1 cm. The right corner is missing.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 4
This leaf is in hand 2.
pästä for päst; welyñe for welñe; lnaṣyeṃ for lännaṣyeṃ; anāsä for anās; mäskiyenträ for mäskīyentär; enäṣälyñe for enäṣṣälñe.
The gap contains about 9 akṣaras.
spaktaṃ for spaktāṃ; nakṣiyenträ for nakṣīyentär; śakeñi for śakkeññi; pāssitse for pāssintse; päñikte for pañäkte.
kattakäñene for kattākäññene; rittaṣäṃ for rittäṣṣäṃ; pañiktäñe for pañäktäññe.
mäsket(rä) sic! Following rittaṣä(ṃ) at the end of this line a singular form must be supplemented here. The supplementation to (s)ai(m) is prompted by line a4. For (a)l(asträ) cf. TA āläṣträ.
On (y)olo(m)eṃ (a)l(asträ ka)r(ts)ene rittaṣä(ṃ) cf. b6 (omä)skenäṣ ālsanträ • || kāswoneyaṃ ritwseñc.
In this ms. the term ‘parents’ is rendered four times by pācer mācer (this leaf, line a3, as well as b4, a1 and a1) and once as mācer pācer (this leaf, line b2).
peleknene for pelaiknene; upadhyāye for upādhyāye; rittaṣṣäṃ for rittäṣṣäṃ.
peleknene sic! and should be corrected to pelaiknene. upadhyāye sic! for upādhyāye. For the supplementation to (ritta)ṣṣ(äṃ) cf. line a3.
sātkesa for sāṃtkesa; kulypele for kwälypelle; tākaṃñca for tākañ-c; abhidhārmä for abhidhārm; yamaṣäṃ-cä for yamaṣṣäṃ-c.
tākaṃñca sic! for tākaṃñcä (= tākaṃñc).
arāñeṣṣe for arāññeṣṣe; alek for allek.

The form c·mp(a)mo is more likely to be supplemented to cimpamo than to cämpamo, since ä in this ms. always appears as i in the vicinity of palatals, such as in repeatedly attested pañikte (for pañäkte) and ñiś (for ñäś). Cf. also .
The gap contains about 15 akṣaras.
mātar for mātär.
The first word in this line is probably (yamaṣäṃ)cä.
yamaṣäle for yamaṣṣälle; star-c for star-ca; upadhyāyenne for upādhyāyenne; weñ-co for weñ-c.
starca sic! for starcä (= starc); upadhyāyenne sic! for upādhyāyenne; upadhyāye sic! for upādhyāye.
upādhyāyetse for upādhyāyentse; spartole for sporttolle; watkäṣälyñe for watkäṣṣälñe; añcāli for añcali; welyñe for welñe; enäṣälyñe for enäṣṣälñe; wärpanale for wärpanalle.
spartole sic! scribal error for sportole.
upadhyāyetse for upādhyāyentse; spaktaṃnne for spaktāṃne; mäskele for mäskelle; śaulasū for śaulassu.
The TB text aiśai te pyāmtsar to wasanpāt yāmu (lines THT 1109 a5 – a1) has a quite exact equivalent in Bhu p. 21, 20-22:

u tsa ha te vi ma la ya śa ma nu śā ṃ sa ka saṃ ma nya te ya ḥ ya śa kā ma ma nu śā si ṣya ti

ci śaulasontä upādhyāyeṃ yaskaske(mar) (t)w(e) /// /// k(a) ci śaulasotsa upadhyāyetsa ñiś wasanpāt yāmu t(e)
tarya weṣṣäle ||
utsahasi tv(aṃ) itthaṃnāmasyopādhy(āyaḥ) utsahasi twaṃ vimalayaśa yaśakāmayānuśāsaka
utsahāma

|| tumeṃ anuh·ke nesalyepi wasaṃpāt yamalye ṣanmireṃ klyauṣalye ikemeṃ pkante aśalle lkalyñe ikene
stamäṣṣale tumeṃ nano anuśāsak(e) (nesa)lyepi en(e)ṅka pästä yänmaṣṣäle ṣañ sthānne ṣmale || tumeṃ karmapāyä weṣeñcatse
tonak rekauna yentukäñe pele weṣ(le) (||)

ko yaḥ itthaṃnāmam anuśāsayiṣy(ati)

no toykk rekauna yeṃtukäñe pele (sāṅ)käśc(ä) weṣä(le) (||)

itthaṃnāmam anuśāsituṃ sacet saṃghasya prāptak(ā)l(aḥ) kṣamate ājñā ca saṃghasya yaḥ saṃgha itthaṃnāmam anuśāsakaṃ saṃ
manyeta yaḥ itthaṃnāmam a(nuś)āsiṣyati eṣā jñ(apt)i(ḥ) (•) (śṛṇot)u bh(a)danta saṃghaḥ ayaṃ yaśakāma yaśasyopasaṃpatprekṣī tam
utsahate vimalayaśam anuśā(situṃ) (sa)ṃ(gho) (anuśā)saka saṃmanyate yaḥ yaśakāmam anuśāsiṣyati

line.tr: solicit you venerable one [as] upādhyāya. (May you venerable one be my upādhyāya.) With (you) venerable one [as] upādhyāya I will be ordained. This

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: [must be] spoken three [times]. Are you able [to be the] upādhyāya for N.N.? ([Yes,] I am able!) Are you, Vimalayaśa, able [to be] the instructor [anuśāsaka] for Yaśakāma?
[Yes,] (I) am able! Thereupon the one who shall be instructor shall lead the novice-to-be-ordained out of earshot, [but] let him stand within eyeshot.
Thereupon the one who shall be instructor shall return, enter [and] take his seat [again]. Thereupon the karmavācaka shall
speak exactly the[se] words in Indic: Let the venerable communi(ty hear!) Who, desiring the ordination of N.N. is (able) [to be] instructor,
to instruct N.N.? (Thereupon) the one who shall be (instructor) shall declare [his] readiness. Thereupon again the karmavācaka
shall say exactly these words in Indic to (the community): Let the venerable community hear! One desiring the ordination of N.N. is able to
instruct N.N. If the present moment suits the community and [if it is] the will of the community, that the community appoints N.N. [as] instructor
who shall instruct N.N., [then] this [is] the proposition: (Let) the venerable community (hear)! This Yaśakāma [i.e. Vimalayaśa], supporter of the ordination of Yaśa[kāma]
is able to instruct this Vimalayaśa [i.e. Yaśakāma]. (The community) appoints (Vimalayaśa [as] instruct)or who will instruct Yaśakāma.

comments.comment: The supplementation and commentaries follow .
According to : iv-v this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

This leaf is preserved almost in full width, with only a smal strip, about 0.5-1 cm high, missing in the centre. The left half consists of 3 pieces and is about 13 cm wide. The right half, consisting of 2 pieces, is about 16 cm wide. To the right of the string hole lines 1-2 are missing over a stretch of 9 and 4 cm respectively.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 4
The leaf is in hand 2.
śaulasontä for śaulasont; śaulasotsa for śaulasontsa; upādhyāyetsa for upadhyāyentsa; wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt.
The last word before the gap can probably be supplemented to twe. upadhyāyetsa sic! for upādhyāyeṃtsa.
The gap contains about 10 akṣaras.
See : b5 and commentary.
weṣṣäle for weṣṣälle.
lkalyñe for lkālñe.
utsahāma should be corrected to utsahāmi. anuh·ke sic! to be corrected to anuśāsake. lkalyñe sic! for lkālyñe.

anu(śā)sake nesalyepi wasaṃ(n)pāt yamalye ṣanmireṃ ... aśalle ... stamäṣṣale: this is an impersonal gerundive construction with a dependent oblique case. The agent noun is in the genitive. On such constructions cf. .
On tumeṃ ... klyauṣalye ikemeṃ pkante aśalle lkalyñe ikene stamäṣṣale cf. Bhī 15 a5f. tataḥ paścāc chravaṇopavicāraṃ vijahayya darśanopavicāre ... (sthā)payitavyā.
stamäṣṣale for stamäṣṣälle; pästä for päst; yänmaṣṣäle for yänmaṣṣälle; ṣmale for ṣmalle; karmapāyä for karmapāy; weṣeñcatse for weṣṣeñcantse.
stamäṣṣale sic! for stamäṣṣäle.
yentukäñe for yentukäññe; weṣle for weṣṣälle.

yentukäñe is an adjectival derivation of yentuke ‘Indian’. yentukäñe pele ‘in Indic’ [lit. ‘in an Indian/Indic way’] belongs with the groups of words used adverbially which are very close to pseudo-bahuvrīhis: cf. e.g. b3 ñäkciṃ pal ‘in a heavenly manner, of the heavenly kind’, b4 ṣeme pälsko päklyauṣso ‘Listen attentively (lit. with a unified mind)!’. On this matter cf. . yentuke is a very early loan from Iranian. On its significance in the study of Iranian-Tocharian exchange of vocabulary, cf. : xviiiff.
yamaṣäle for yamaṣṣälle; karmavācaketse for karmavācakentse.
yeṃtukäñe for yentukäññe; sāṅkäścä for sāṅkäśc; weṣäle for weṣṣälle.
toyk\k sic!
On yeṃtukäñe cf. commentary to line a5 above.
anuśāsaka must be corrected to anuśāsakaṃ.

recto.line: ye ṣāṃ mā yu ṣmaṃ tāṃ kṣa m· vi ma l· /// /// ya ḥ ya śa kā ma ma nu śā si ṣya ti te tu ṣṇīṃ ye ṣā[ṃ] na kṣa

line.tr: Whoever [of the] venerable ones agree (to appoint) Vimal(ayaśa [as] instructor), who shall instruct Yaśakāma, these [be] silent. Whoever do not

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: agree, these shall speak. The (com)munity has appointed Vimalayaśa [as] (instructor), who shall instruct Yaśakāma. The community agrees
for they [are] silent. Thus you shall assert this. (Thereupon) the one to be instructor shall go out [and] shall interrogate the novice to be ordained
[with regard to] any obstacles [antarāyikā dharmāḥ]: (Listen, venerable one! This [now] for you [is]) the time to speak the truth. This [is] the time to speak according to the facts. Therefore
Now I will ask you [about] what [it is with] you.
I will ask you, how it is with you, [and] thereupon ([you] shall speak:) what is, (as it is); what is (not) [you] shall have be known just as it is not: [1.] Are you male?
[2.] Are you full 20 years of age? [3.] (You are) not (a slave)? [4.] You are (not other people’s peon? [5.] You have not been bought? [6.] You are not a debtor by bankruptcy? [7.]
You have not been bought, have you?

You are not a mercenary [or: official?] of the king? [8.] (You have) not (sinned against) the king? [9.] You are (not secretly(?)) considering a conspiracy against the king? [10.] You are not indebted to anyone, neither a little
nor much? [11.] Now among men there are the following diseases: black leprosy, white leprosy, scrofula, tuberculosis [and] epilepsy. You do not suffer from one of these diseases?

[12.] Are your father [and] mother [still] alive? [13.] Have you asked their permission [and] (have you also received) the permission to go from the house? [14.] You have never been a monk before? If he says: I was a monk [before], he shall be asked:
«You haven't been monk before, have you?» If he says, «I have been monk», [he is] to be asked: …

Did you give up (the) commandment(s) with [careful] consideration [and] (do you [now, after careful consideration,] wish to return [to them]? Thus) the (instruct)or shall inquire about obstacles. After the instructor has asked the one to be ordained

comments.comment: The supplementation and commentaries follow .
According to : iv-v, this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

From this leaf 2 large fragments are preserved: from the left side, consisting of 2 pieces and about 11 cm wide; and the right half of the leaf, consisting of 2 pieces (of the smaller of which, about 2 cm high, only the verso is preserved) and about 13.5 cm wide. In the centre a strip of 2.5-8 cm is missing.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 4
The leaf is in hand 2.
yeṣāṃm sic!
The gap contains about 9 syllables.
bhaṣaṃtāṃ must be corrected to bhāṣaṃtāṃ.
yale for yalle; wasaṃnpāt for wasaṃpāt.
pkänte-yamiñana for pkänte-yamiññana; prekṣale for prekṣalle; welyñetse for welñentse; preśiya for preściya.
tuṣṇīṃm sic! dhārayataḥ must be corrected to dhārayata. auspa is certainly to be read as such.
Here auspa, otherwise known as an adverbial ‘truly, indeed’, here is an adjective ‘true, BHS bhūta’.
The gap contains 8 akṣaras.
pkänte yamiñana wäntarwa are the “obstacles” [Skt. antarāyikā dharmāḥ], i.e. circumstances preventing ordination.
nestä for nest.
śarsaṣṣäle sic! for śarsäṣṣäle.
The gap contains 7 akṣaras.
ikäṃ-pikwalañe for ikäṃ-pikwalaññe; nestä for nest.
temaṣe: separation into individual words is uncertain. weretemaṣe, on the basis of its equivalent in the Chinese version, must mean something like ‘debtor by bankruptcy (?)’ (cf. ).
The gap contains about 12 akṣaras.
nestä for nest; lāntäścä for lāntäśc; palskanatä for pälskanat; ketra for ketara; ca for kca.
wantareśce probably corresponds to Skt. bhaṭa ‘mercenary’. The associated Nom.Pl. wäntreśśi a4 is translated as ‘vermogenden’ (i.e. ‘men of property’) in .
The last syllable before the gap must be read either as k[a] or k[ā].
On the basis of the Chinese version kastuna, only attested here, must mean something like ‘secret assaults (?), conspiracy (?)’ (cf. ).
ca peri is probably to be regarded as a bahuvrīhi (ca-peri) meaning ‘having something as debt’.
The gap contains 8 akṣaras.
tsamo = Skt. prabhūta ‘much, plenty, numerous’, Adv. ‘exceedingly’, pace , who regards tsamo as a noun meaning ‘tumour, excrescence; increase, growth, welfare, prosperity, thriving’.
eṅkwetse for eṅkwentse.
koṣṭä = Skt. kuṣṭha ‘(black) leprosy’; piśträ =? Skt. gaṇḍa ‘scrofula’; kṣai = Skt. kṣaya ‘tubercolosis’; apasmār = Skt. apasmāra ‘epilepsy’.
nesaṃ-cä for nesaṃ-c; laṃtsi for lantsi; ṣaiytä for ṣait; prekṣale for prekṣalle.
plāksatai is a Pt. III of plāk-, Kaus. III ‘to ask for permission’.
kre·e (no certain supplementation), perhaps ‘permission’ [cf. TA ke].
The supplementation of the first syllable after the gap to no is relatively certain.
ymasu for imassu; śäkṣapātänta for śikṣapātänta; anuśāsaketse for anuśāsakentse; wasaṃnpāt for wasaṃpāt.

(ṣäle)

line.tr: about any obstacle(s), (he shall enter [again and] pay homage to the community.) After having paid homage he shall rise, fold [his] hands

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: together [and] say: [He has] been instructed. There(upon the whole community) shall (speak): If he [is] pure, he shall come. If he is pure,
Then the saṃgha is to say together, «yadi pariśuddha āgacchatu! [If he is pure, let him come!]». If he is pure, then the anuśāsaka is to ask this: … (cf 53, 87)
the instructor (shall) speak thus: [He is] (pure) with regard to obstacles. Thereupon the instructor shall lead in the novice to be
ordained [and] tell [him] (to ask the community for [his] ordination.) Thereupon he [i.e. the novice] shall revere the feet of the Ācāryas each, from the eldest to the youngest,
(fold [his] hands together(?) [before(?)]) each of them, look up into [each one’s] face [and say]: I ask you to ordain me!
After (having asked,) (in) this way, everyone (to ordain [him]), he shall be led again to the karmavācaka [and] before [him]
[he] shall be set. [This one speaks to him:] Here (you have seized) the three [monks’] clothes [and] the eating bowl [and] asked (for a teacher). Now here you shall ask to be ordained.
Ordination here is (an excellent thing), comparable to a Cintāmaṇi-jewel: Like a human,
[when] he obtains the Cintāmaṇi-jewel, will acquire every kind of (goods of happiness of the world [and]) remove (poverty) – [for] all wishes are granted him –
just so (is the) ordained (one(?) Now here) the difficult process to [reaching] this excellent, magnificent thing shall be started.

According to : iv-v this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

From this leaf 2 large fragments are preserved: one from the left side, about 9 cm wide, and the right half of the leaf, about 13 cm wide. Between the two fragments about 6-9 cm are missing. On the left margin a strip of about 0.5 x 3 cm, which contained the leaf number, is lost.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 4
The leaf is in hand 3.
antarāyä for antarāy; yamaṣälle for yamaṣṣälle.
antarāyä should be corrected to antarāyänta.
The gap contains 12 akṣaras.
krui for kwri; mistaken ārstare for astare.
ārstare sic! to be corrected to āstare or astare.
On krui ārstare tākaṃ tumeṃ anuśā(sa)kentse te weṣṣä(lle) cf. Bhī 17 a3 sacet pariśuddhā bhavati rahonuśāsikayā vaktavyā.
anuśākentse for anuśāsakentse; wasaṃnpāt for wasaṃpāt.
anuśākentse sic! to be corrected to anuśāsakentse (twice). ddharmai sic! for dharmaiḥ
ṣanmīreṃ for ṣanmireṃ; eneṃṅka for eneṅka.
The first word after the gap is probably yāṣtsi There is a clearly recognizable trace of a ṣ.

The words putanti ‘senior, eldest (in a monastic community)’’ and b1 nawanti ‘newcomer, youngest (in a monastic community)’ come from Middle Indic. putanti goes back to Prakrit *vuḍḍhantiya vel sim. (cf. BHS vṛddhānta ‘elder’s end or place’) and nawanti goes back to Prakrit *ṇavantiya vel sim. (cf. BHS navānta ‘the junior’s end or place’ - the meaning of both BHS vṛddhānta and navakānta were already identified correctly by ). Both words display typical Prakrit features: shortening of long vowels before double consonants according to the two-mora rule, and the replacement of ṛ by u after labials. The change from word initial v to p and of word internal ddh to t is due to the Tocharian adaptation of voiced consonants.

The TB phrase putantimeṃ waiptār aśarintaṃts paiyne wināṣṣälle ... eṃṣke nawanti täṅtsi has a nice parallel in the Bhikṣuṇī-Vinaya (Mā-L) (), where it says: vṛddhāntāto prabhṛti sarvāsāṃ pādā śirasā vanditavyāḥ yāvan navakāntaṃ. ‘Starting from the end of the line (or place) of the newly ordained monks’ (). Cf. also . 19, 404.
paiyne for paine; wasaṃnpāt for wasaṃpāt.

paiyne wināṣṣälle corresponds to the Skt. pādā śirasā vanditavyāḥ of the Bhikṣuṇī-Vinaya (Mā-L), § 38; cf. also b4 paiyne wīnāṣäle: paiyne wināsk- lit. “to revere the feet”, just like Skt. pādau śirasā vand- and Pāli pāde sirasā vand-, means “to bow down at someone’s feet”(cf. ).
täṅtsi for täṅktsi; karmawācakeś for karmavācakeś.
The first word after the gap could perhaps be supplemented to yayāṣormeṃ.
lamäṣṣalle sic! for lamäṣṣälle.
Mistaken ta for tane; wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt.
ta ñake should probably be corrected to tane ñake.
The gap contains 9 akṣaras.
wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt.
snaitsäñenta for snaitsäññenta.
lyecciṃ sic! for lyaiccäṃ. It is the Subj. II of litk- Kaus. ‘remove’.
knaskentär is the Prs. of kän- Kaus. ‘fulfil’.
wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt; wakīce for wakice; yamaṣäle for yamaṣṣälle.
The last word before the gap can perhaps be supplemented to yāmu.
The gap contains 8 akṣaras.
