line.tr: You have here asked each [and] every monk (down to the youngest(?)) to ordain [you]. But now you shall ask the community as a whole
to ordain [you]. If the community as a whole (agrees by sitting still), you will be ordained. [If only] one [single] monk
If the whole saṃgha (agrees), [even if] only (through remaining silent), you will be ordained. If only one monk stops you, you cannot be ordained.
hinders you, you will not be ordained. What words I give you now [and] here to say, this say loudly, for the hearing of the whole community!
The words which I tell you to say, say that aloud!
Say: Let (the venerable community) pay heed to this! I, Yaśakāma, Yaśa’s [= abbrev. of Vimalayaśa] [candidate] to be ordained,
May the worthy saṃgha pay attention!
(ask) the community (to) ordain [me] with Yaśa [as] (upā)dhyāya. May the community lift me up, may the community enable my ordination
(out of) compassion! (This [must] be spoken three [times].) The noble community, from a loving disposition,
has, by sitting still, agreed to ordain you. (Let the venerable) community (hear)! I, Yaśakāma, Yaśa’s [candidate] wishing to be ordained,
(ask) the community (for) [my] ord(ination). May the community lift me up, may the community ordain
me out of compassion. Thus (a second [and] a third time) [it must] be (spoken). 3. But now the being to be ordained shall
(be asked) about obstacles. Why so? Because at the time of the Buddha, some beings, who

comments.comment: The supplementation and commentaries follow .

TB: aiśai te yāmträ (aṣanīke sāṅk) ñiś yaśakāme yaśentse wasanpāt yamaṣälle • su ñiś saṅkameṃ wasanpāt y(askaskemar upā)dhyāyeṃ yaśentsa • kauc ñiś sāṅk pannoy yātäṣṣi ñi sāṅk wasanpāt āñmālāśälyñe(sa)

Skt.: (samanvāharatu bhadan)t(a) saṃghaḥ ahaṃ yaśakāma yaśasy=opasa(ṃ)patprekṣī so ‘haṃ saṃghād up(asaṃpadaṃ yācā)mi --------------------- avalaṃbatu māṃ saṃghaḥ upasaṃpā〈da〉yatu māṃ 〈saṃ〉ghaḥ anukampām upādāya
According to : iv-v this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.
From this leaf 2 large fragments are preserved: one from the left side, about 10 cm wide, and the right half of the leaf, about 13 cm wide. In between about 6 cm are missing.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 4
The leaf is in hand 3.
yamaṣäle for yamaṣṣälle; ta for tane; ṣṣeme for ṣeme; wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt.
na sic! Perhaps one should read ta, as a scribal error for tane? ṣṣeme sic!
The gap contains about 10 akṣaras.
yaskaṣälle for yaskaṣṣälle; krui for kwri; wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt; yātaṃñ-c for yātaṃ-c; teṅkäñ-c for teṅkäṃ-c.
The gap contains about 6 akṣaras.
teṅkäṃ is the initially accented 3rdSub.Sg. II of täṅk- ‘hinder’.
wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt; yātaṃñ-c for yātaṃ-c; weñau-ś for weñau-c.-
The gap contains about 3-4 akṣaras.
klyaussa for klyauṣtsisa; wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt; yamaṣälle for yamaṣṣälle.
klyaussa sic! scribal error for klyaussisa.
The gap contains about 6 akṣaras.
The Tocharian text from aiśai te yāmträ to āñmālāṣäly(ñ)e(sa) is the translation of the Sanskrit text following in lines b2-4 (for a further parallel cf. also the Bhī 19 a2-4):
wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt.

kauc pannoy corresponds to Skt. avalaṃbatu; as a Skt. equivalent, however, one would rather expect ulluṃpatu ‘shall lift’, which, indeed, is attested in Bhī 133, 17 (= a3) and the Vinayapiṭaka II, p. 277 in the same context.
The gap contains 4 akṣaras.
yātäṣṣi wasanpāt translates Skt. upasaṃpā〈da〉yatu.
wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt; āñmālāśälyñesa for añmalāṣṣälñese.
āñmālāṣälyñe sic!
The gap contains about 7 akṣaras.
wasanpāt for wasaṃpāt.
saṃghaḥ ahaṃ yaśakāma sic! Class.Skt. saṃgho 'haṃ yaśakāmo.
The gap contains 6 akṣaras.
Below up(a-) the akṣara śa seems to have been inserted - where this is supposed to belong remains unclear. upasaṃpāyatu sic! scribal error for upasaṃpādayatu.
māṃghaḥ: scribal error for māṃ sāṃghaḥ.
The gap contains 7 akṣaras.
pkänte for pkante.
The gap contains about 6 akṣaras.

(ṅkantse)

line.tr: [were] not worthy, went from the house here [and] (were ordained, [although they]) [were] endowed with (ev)il deeds. Thereupon [in] many beings

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: disbelief arose. The Tīrthikas reproached: (They do damage to the) teaching. To keep away this reproach the Omniscient, the Buddha, commanded
to enquire about obstacles. Just like juice that is excellent [and] exquisite shall be poured into an undamaged vessel, where it will thus retain its taste,

line.n: a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3
line.tr: [Just] as when [the taste of a] juice is excellent and distinguished, it is to be poured into an intact bowl where it will keep; or when a jewel is splendid, it is not to be put away, [but] it is to be put in a firmly [closed] treasury, [or] it is to be taken charge of by a trustworthy person; or [just] as when the son of a king is to be made king, who has intact senses [lit. who is complete of senses] and masters [lit. is provided with] the arts, [then] the ministers of the land agree to make him king—comparable to that a being who has intact senses [and] does not bear [lit. is provided with] bad deeds is worthy to be a son of the omniscient Buddha, of the cakravartin king of the law.
or [like] a jewel that is most beautiful shall not be put (aside(?)) somewhere, [but shall] be put into [a] solid treasury [or shall] be let have by a trustworthy man,
or like a prince who is impeccable with regard to [his] mental powers [and]

[who] is well endowed with the arts, .... shall be made (king) [and] the ministers of the country gladly agree that he be made (king, just so) the being that is impeccable with regard to [its] mental powers
and not endowed with evil deeds, is worthy to be a son of the Omniscient, the Buddha, the law-king ruling the world.
Such a being the Buddha has commanded to be ordained. I will here [and] now ask you about them. Say as the matter
Now I will ask you this here. How the matter is, say it in that way!
is! Let the venerable community hear! This Yaśakāma, Yaśa’s [= abbrev. of Vimalayaśa] [candidate] to be ordained
asks the community to ordain [him] (with Yaśa [as] upādhyāya). If the present moment pleases the community and it [be] the wish of the community

comments.comment: The supplementation and commentaries follow .
According to : iv-v this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.
This leaf is preserved in its full width and consists of 4 pieces. To the right of the string hole lines 1-2 are missing over a stretch of 7 and 5 cm respectively.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 4-5
The leaf is in hand 3.
onolmeṃntso for onolmeṃts.
The supplementation (keke)n(o)ṣ is based on yolaina yāmorntasa mā kekenu in b2.
The gap contains about 8 akṣaras.
śāsa is probably to be supplemented to śāsa(näntse) (sic!) A trace of the s of the genitive ending is still visible.
The gap contains about 6 akṣaras.
wakītse for wakitse; bhājanne for bhājaṃne.
saille is the Ger. II of sain- ‘lean on, rely on’.
perak for perāk.

yasna (Pl. Fem.), probably ‘treasury’, seems to correspond to TA Pl. pāśināñ. To this also would belong yäsnā- ( b1), which in and has been corrected and supplemented to yästā(r)- ‘the double amount each’, but which rather should be supplemented to read yäsnā(meṃ) ‘from the treasuries’.
perak sic! for perāk.
intrintasa for indrintasa.
amācinta for amācänta; ceu for cau; intrintintasa for indrintasa.
y(ā)mts(i) – [m]p·: the value of the first element of the ligatura remains uncertain. Within the given context it may be possible to restore (tu)[m]p(a).
cakrawartti for cakravārtti.
nessi for nestsi; ceu for cau; wasatpāt for wasaṃtpāt.
wasantpāt for wasaṃtpāt.

The equation TB aṣ(an)ī(k)e = Skt. bhadanta is remarkable. It shows that Tocharian monks related Skt. bhadanta attributively – either as the first element of a compound (bhadanta- or as a Nom.Sg.Masc. (= bhadantaḥ) – to saṃghaḥ: “Let/May the venerable community hear!”. Among European scholars, however, it is usually regarded as a Voc.Pl.: “Let/May, oh venerable ones, the community hear!”. On a historical explanation of bhadanta cf. q.v.
The gap contains about 7 akṣaras.
se has no correspondence in the Skt. text.

The section of Tocharian text beginning with klyauṣi translates the Skt. text following below ( b5 – a2). The Skt. version may be supplemented with the help of the text restored from Turfan finds by §37, p. 85: TB: klyauṣi aṣ(an)ī(k)e sā(ṅk) se yaśakāme yaśentse wasanpāt yamaṣṣälle • se saṅkameṃ wasanpāt yaskas(trä upādhyāyeṃ yaśentsa) k(ru)i saṅkantse yainmu preke ārttoy watkäṣṣälyñe ṣpä sa(ṅkantse) /// Skt.: śṛṇotu bhadanta saṃghaḥ ayaṃ (yaśakāma yaśasy=upasaṃpatpre)k(ṣ)ī -- saṃghād upadaṃ yācate yaśasyo(pādhyāye)na sacet sa(ṃ)ghasya prā(ptakālaḥ kṣamata ājñā ca saṃghasya) ....
wasantpāt for wasaṃtpāt; krui for kwri; watkäṣṣälyñe for watkäṣṣälñe.
The equation TB ārttoy = Skt. kṣamate allows us to better define the meaning of ārtt-. It thus means ‘to favour, approve of, love, praise, Skt. kṣam-’, which makes sense in all attested occurrences.
The supplementation to sa(ṅkantse) is prompted by the Skt. model saṃghasya, cf. also a1.

line.tr: he/they(?) shall (ask) him about other obstacles. ([On] offences(?)) such as [1.] patricide [pitṛvadha], [2.] matricide [mātṛvadha],

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: [3.] killing of the Arhat [arhadvadha], [4.] dividing the community [saṃghabheda], [5.] malicious shedding of the blood of a Buddha [tathagataduṣṭacittarudhirotpāda],

[6.] the causing of heretic views, and so on, (the community(?)) shall (also) be heard. Of whatever reproach against this person, however, he [i.e. the instructor], is doubtful, this shall be asked. Whatever from now on
If, however, he has doubts about this person with respect to this reproach, this is to be investigated [lit. questioned]. (cf 56, 92–93)
you hear from a monk, a nun or a householder: This [or] that now(?) is an obstacle!, all this do not regard! This,
so far, the Buddha due to [his] omniscience, saw as obstacles. This then he commanded you be asked, [and] this now I have asked you. From this, however,
nothing was with you. [Therefore] be without doubt! You are without obstacle. Your vessel is clean. You are worthy to be a place of the prātimokṣa-
taste. You are worthy to be a son of the Omniscient, the Buddha, the law-king ruling the world. Since
in the meantime you have bowed at the feet [of the exalted one], seized garb [and] eating bowl [and] have asked for a teacher,
You will not have the ordination (unless there are no objections against your) application [invitation] to the ordination. I will now say that through which you will have the ordination. (cf 57, 94)
[and since] ordination will not be yours ([if] obstacles hinder(?)) the proposition(?) of ordination, I will now speak that, through which ordination will be yours: [In Skt.]:
Let the venerable community hear! This (Yaśakāma, Yaśa’s [= abbrev. of Vimalayaśa] [candidate] wishing to be ordained) asks the community to ordain [him] with Yaśa

comments.comment: The supplementation and commentaries follow .
According to : iv-v this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.
This leaf is preserved in its full width and consists of 6 pieces. The damage is similar to . To the right of the string hole lines 1-2 are missing over s atretch of 10 and 5 cm respectively.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 5
This leaf is in hand 3.
aloṅkna for alloṅkna.

The last sign before the gap (above: [o]) could also be read as [tu]. The second readable sign after the gap (above: ·ñ·) could also be read as ·r·, ·lä or ā, and the following k· (as above) could also be a r· or a ·u.
The gap contains about 9 akṣaras.

These lines contain a list of the five capital sins (TB anantārśänta = Skt. ānantaryāṇi), to wit pātär māträ arahante kāwäly(ñ)e (= Skt. pitṛvadha, mātṛvadha and arhadvana), sāṅk wi-p(ā)k(e yama)lyñ(e) (= Skt. saṃghabheda) and (mamāntau-pä)lsko pañäktente yasar lyucalyñe (= Skt. tathāgataduṣṭacittarudhirotpāda), as well as a sixth, heresy (TB ankaiṃpilko erälñe = Skt. mithyādṛṣṭi). On the pañcānantaryāṇi cf. Dharmasaṃgraha 60; Mvy., 2324-2328, , and (Nr. 26-30).
arahante for arhānte; kāwälye for kāwälñe; wī for wi; yyamalyñe for yamalñe.
kāwälye sic! and should be corrected to kāwälyñe. The sequence [·y·] – [·y]ñ· is most likely to be supplemented to yyamalyñe (sic!).
kattākeṃnmeṃ for kattākeṃmeṃ; tam for tamp.
Separating the sequence tetamtsake into te tam tsa ke is a likely option. antaray sic! for antarāy.
mistaken lyā for lyāka.
lyā should be corrected to lyāka.
prekuwa: 1stPt.III Act. of prek- ‘ask’. (= pärk-, cf. ).
nessi for nestsi.
antaray sic! for antarāy.
śmoñña for ścmoñña; nessi for nestsi; pañaktentse for pañäktentse; cakkravārtti for cakravārtti.
pañaktentse should be corrected to pañäktentse. The following dot is misplaced and can be ignored.
epiṅte for epiṅkte; paiyne for paine; ta for tane.
atiṣṭhit sic! for adhiṣṭhit. The ta at the end of this line may be an error for tane.
wasatpāt for wasaṃtpāt; tākaṃñc for tākañ-c; cesa for kucesa.

The sequence [·ta] after the gap may also be read as [·ñ·]; the following naṅkeṃ could also be read as taṅkeṃ. If so, this is a 3rd Pl.Sub.Act. that has been transferred to thematic inflection. On the inflection of the athematic Sub. class I in TB cf. .
upadaṃ must be corrected to upasaṃpadaṃ.
The gap contains about 11 akṣaras.
cf. a4 - b1 and commentary.

line.tr: ([as] upādhyāya). If (the present moment suits) the community (and [if it] is the wish of the community, this we will ask Yaśakāma with Yaśa [as] upādhyāya)
(in the midst of the community) about any obstacles. (This is the proposition. Listen, venerable one! This [is] the time of truth for you. This [is] the time of speaking the truth.)
(Whatever) we ask (you), thereupon (the truth you shall) speak, (the truth) according to the (truth, and say untruth as untruth.)
[1.] Are you (male?) [2.] Are you full 20 years of age? [3.] (You are) not (a slave?) [4.] (You have) not been bought? ...............

[8.] You have not sinned against the king? [9.] You are not (secretly(?) considering a conspiracy against the king? [10.] You are not indebted to anyone, neither a little nor much? [11.] Now among men)
there are the following d(iseases: black leprosy, white leprosy, scrofula, tuberculosis [and] epilepsy. You) do (not) suf(fer from one of these diseases?)
[12.] Are your father [and] mother [still] alive? [13.] Have you received the permission (of your father [and] mother)? ......
....[15.] (Did you(?)) with [careful] consideration .... [16.] (Have you [received] the three clothes and the bowl) completely? ....
.... enormous roaring ....
(Such a (?) ... believ)able thing, however, (to the?) helpful te(acher(?)) ....

comments.comment: The supplementation and commentaries follow .
According to : iv-v this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

From this leaf 2 fragments are preserved: one larger fragment around the string hole, consisting of 5 pieces and about 6-9 cm wide; to the right of this at a distance of about 2 cm there is a smaller fragment, about 2.5 cm wide and containing remnants of 3 lines. At the left margin 1-3.5 cm are missing. The leaf number is not preserved.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 5
This leaf is in hand 3.

The main part is a larger fragment from the top right side of the leaf, consisting of 3 pieces, about 3.5-8.5 cm wide and containing remnants of 4 lines. There is another small fragment (, cf. ), inserted at the beginning of lines a 1, a 2, b 4 and b 5 below. This is from the top left margin, possibly the corner, about 2 cm wide. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. line.tr: (is covered(?)) [and] yet the sun is visible ...., (compara)able (to this) is the average [form of] self-discipline. What (then is the third form?) of (self-)discipline?

(self-discipline(?)) .... unstained ....
(Now?) I will (proclaim to you) whereby self-discipline (may be obtained).
... Since(?) these .... seven (salutary) acts(?) [karmapathas(?)] .... in 21 wa(ys)
may be .... obtained, therefore you shall raise desire (for the [beneficial] effects(?) of) ordi(nation). Why so? Because he(re these(?)) dharmas ...
... , however, (are(?)) an excellent t(hing. Who[ever]) has the wish (for this) [and] the desire, he (will) obt(ain) this. But why shall one

From this leaf 3 fragments are preserved: one from the left half of the leaf around the string hole, about 4 cm wide; one from the centre of the leaf, top margin, about 8 cm wide and containing remnants of 4 lines; and the top right corner, 3.5 cm wide and containing the remnants of 3 lines. The leaf number is not preserved.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 5
This leaf is in hand 3.
ywārśkaññe for ywārśkāññe; saṃwarä for saṃvar.
At the beginning of this line there is a gap of about 5 akṣaras. The [k·] may also be a [t·] or a [n·]. Between tä and (tase)mane about 8 akṣaras are missing.
The cross above ywarśkāññe does not seem to be of any significance, since the akṣaras added below the line were apparently deleted later.
paintsa prob. ‘in the evening (?)’; ksartsa prob. ‘in the morning (?)’, cf. TA ksär.
There is no certain identification of trekne by its form (possibly a Loc.) alone. Possibly (but not likely) to be corrected to trekte ‘big’ or connected to tärrek ‘blind’.
About 5-6 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line. Between wa and mā no about 6 akṣaras are missing.
About 5 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line. Between laune (separation into segments uncertain) and ·i·ai there is a gap of about 7, after krāke there is one of about 8 akṣaras.
cesa for kucesa.
At the beginning of this line there is a gap of about 5 akṣaras. The text breaks off after this line. The rest of the leaf is blank.

At the beginning of this line about 7 akṣaras are missing. This first line seems to have contained a text in Sanskrit. Above and below this line a rather inexpert hand has drawn lines, which may have been intended as a frame for the text. To the end of this line about 22 akṣaras are missing.
yāmtsi sic! and hardly to be read as yāmtsī The last word in this line may perhaps be restored to read śp(ālmeṃ).
About 5 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line, and after yāmtsi there is a gap of about 9. To the end of this line about 13 akṣaras are missing. camtä may be a scribal error for campät.

ṣukt karmadha[·t·] is unclear. It is not clear either if the phrase can be corrected and supplemented to ṣukt karma(pa)tä(n)[t](a), since Buddhist literature usually mentions ten karmapathas (‘ways of conduct’). karmadha[·t·]: °dha[kt·] is a possibility, but perhaps one should only read °dha[t·]? The last word in this line must be supplemented to a plural form of klautke.
At the beginning of this line there is a gap of about 5 akṣaras, and after toya(k) about 6 are missing. Beneath the gap between [·m· y·] and ikäṃ and in a somewhat smaller script it says k[n]al[i].
ñyāsä for ñyās.
wasaṃtpāt: supplement thus or to a adjectival derivation of it.
About 4 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line. Before ñyāsä the gap contains about 7 akṣaras.
wakītse for wakitse; kwälpelle for kwälypelle.
The supplementation to kälpāṣṣäm ‘will obtain’ is prompted by the still visible remains. On the use of the present tense to express future events see .
About 5 akṣaras are missing at the beginning of this line, before ñyās there is a gap of about 8.

line.tr: raise desire for this? Because .... [is] done. Here (there are) three excellent beings, the Buddha,

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: the Pratyekabuddha [and] the Arhat, (who reach the nirvāṇa. The Buddha) at (this(?) time labours [for] a hundred kalpas [and] three asaṃkhyeyas,
then (goes) from the house ([and] obtains the dignity of the Buddha.) The Khaḍgaviṣāṇa [rhinoceros], the Pratyekabuddha, labours [for] (a hundred) kalpas,
then g(oes) from the house ([and] obtains the dignity of the Pratyekabuddha.) The śrāvakas [students], [like] the venerable Śāriputra and so on, labour ([for] sixty kalpas),
then (go) from the house ([and] obtain the dignity of Arhat.) (There is no) thing, [that is] more excellent than this [= ordination?], (that the good beings)
would have considered good. Because these (people) .... For (three ... effects) can be obt)ained there(from).
What are these? ([1.] Who is ordained, he) obtains the seed of (rele)ase (from the saṃsāra). Comparable to Indra’s vajra
– just like (in the) parable, [where] Indra, [if] the vajra falls from [his] (hands, ne)ver (reaches) [his] aims here, the earth
glows, mountains, water, wind .... – (but reaches [his] destination, [if] he holds it fast(?)), and only relies on it – comparable to this [is]

the self-discipline of the prātimokṣa. (Who at a)ny time (loses this self-discipline, he) does not reach his aim (of ordination(?) [and] remains(?)) outside (the) nirvāṇa. ([But] why do) the good beings (sow)

line.tr: (the seed) of release from the saṃsāra? (Because the saṃsāra is) mean, sinful(?) [and] inconstant. (Being reborn again and again),
dying again and again, (being separated from loved ones), meeting with not-loved-ones [and] (not reaching) the wishes one has:
in short, (the bundle of the) five constituents is no more than suffering. Therefore the good beings (sow the seed of) release from the saṃsāra.
This (for you is) the first (effect) of ordination. [2.] What is [this]: The merit [from ordination] is more than itself [i.e. ordination]? [Answer:] (This merit) is (without)

measure [and] number. Without measure [and] number (are the four elements. Just as it is not possible to measure out) this earth (with) steps or (to measure out) the airspace (with) one’s arms outstretched,
(to) trick(le) the ocean in droplets (or the sun(?)) .... (Whatever things)
may stop for him, these four (elements will not stop for him(?) Just as these) four elements have neither measure nor number, just so this merit of ord(ination) [has]
neither measure nor number [and] can be (obtained by you(?)). Whence is the obtainment of this? From just these (elements, earth,and so on,)
is obtainment, in so far as it [=merit] can be obtained in this way from the (organic and inorganic elements). How much (in(?)) the whole (saṃsāra(?)) ....
the beings of the five births ...., (so much(?)) merit can be obtained in ... (ways(?)). How much (in(?)) the whole saṃ(sāra(?)) ...

comments.comment: The supplementation and commentaries follows .
TB (nano nano cme)lle – Skt. jātiḥ
TB nano nano srukall(e) – Skt. maranam
TB larenmeṃ tsrelle – Skt. priyaviprayogaḥ
TB an(ai)wace(ṃ)mpa ṣe śmalyñe – Skt. apriyasaṃprayogaḥ
TB ritauwa akā(lkäntats mā-källālyñe) – Skt. yad apīcchan paryeṣamāṇo na labhate
TB (au)ltsorsa ka piś-antse(ṣṣe perpette la)k(l)e ka ste – Skt. saṃkṣiptena pañcopādānaskandhā duḥkham
According to : iv-v this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

From this leaf 3 fragments are preserved: one from the left side to the string hole, consisting of 3 pieces and about 6.5 cm wide; a larger fragment from the right half of the leaf, about 9 cm wide; and, attaching to this, at the lower margin a small fragment, about 3.5 cm wide and containing the remnants of a single line.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 5-6
This leaf is in hand 3.
tsälpāṣ- sic! and should probably be corrected to tsälpālyñeṣ·, an adjectival form in -ṣṣe.
akritāññe ca. ‘sin’ is a loan from Iranian (cf. Sogd. ’krt’nyh ‘sin’).
The gap contains about 9-10 akṣaras, and to the end of the line about 7-8 are missing.

These lines contain a (shortened) Tocharian version of the well-known definition of the noble truth “suffering”. In comparison to the Skt. version, as it can be found in CPS, varga 14.5, for instance, the following correspondences ensue:
Mistaken anaiwacempa for anaiwacceṃmpa; akālkäntats for akālkäntaṃts.

-lle at the beginning of this line is the remains of a Ger. of the root täm- 'be born'. sruk·[ll](e) is certainly to be read srukalle, therefore the preceding must be restored to read nano nano cmelle (as above). If srukelle is assumed, the preceding would have to be read as (nano nano tänmaṣṣä)lle, which, however, for reasons of space would not appear to be a possibility. The last word in this line must be supplemented to either akālkänta or akālkäntats.
The gap contains about 5 akṣaras, and to the end of the line about 7-8 are missing.
tsälpālyñe for tsälpālñe.

piś antse sic! A possible supplementation could be piś-antseṣṣe perpette (cf. : b 1 piṃś-atseṣṣe perpette) vel sim. The last word in this line is most likely to be supplemented to tsälpālyñe (as above) or an adjectival derivation of it.
The gap contains about 5 akṣaras, and to the end of the line about 7 are missing.
wasātpatäntse for wasaṃtpātäntse.
The first word after the gap may perhaps be supplemented to kuse.

(ku)se ste ce yarpo temeṃ māka mäs(k)eträ literally means “(Wha)t is [it], that merit is more than this?” The ce- clause represents the subject of the superordinate clause and must therefore be identified as subject clause.

The gap contains about 5 akṣaras, and to the end of the line about 6 are missing. The particular shape of the i-hook in mäsketrä ·i is caused by the ligature lyñe (supplementation certain) right above it. Cf. a 2 ritauwa.
akāś for akāśe.

The first word after the gap may perhaps be supplemented to mäkte. The word before akāś, of which only the ·i can be read, is the remains of a bisyllabic infinitive in -tsi, which, however, cannot be restored with any certainty.
The gap contains about 8 akṣaras.
samudrä for samudtär.

The last word before the gap (su-) is the remains of an infinitive, and may perhaps be restored to read sumästsi. An alternative reading of [l]y·y·[t·k·] after the gap would also be [l]y·y·[t·r·] or [l]y·y·[t·u·].
The gap contains about 11 akṣaras.
wäntarwats for wäntarwaṃts.
The gap contains about 8 akṣaras.
yärpotse for yärpontse; mistaken kutemeṃ for kutameṃ.
kutemeṃ sic! for kutameṃ. But cf. also a 2 kutemeṃ kutemeṃ (= Skt. yato yataḥ).
The gap contains about 5 akṣaras, and to the end of the line about 7 are missing.
The gap contains about 8 akṣaras, and to the end of the line about 7 are missing.
piś-cmalaṣṣi sic! and to be corrected to piś-cmelaṣṣi. The first word after the gap ([·ā·ek]tsa) could also be read as [-n]tsa.
The gap contains about 6 akṣaras, and to the end of the line about 7 are missing.

line.tr: ... twenty(?) .... In (this way) it [=merit] can be obtained from the organic elements. In which

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: way (can it be obtained from) the inorganic (elements)? In this way, from [the element] earth [and] from the atoms of the earth, self-discipline may be
obtained: From all green, (white(?) [and] black(?)) seeds, whatever seeds there are near or far,
from all [of them] self-discipline can be obtained. (Thus) it can be obtained from (all organic [and] inor)ganic elements. Just as
the organic [and] inorganic (elements have neither measure nor number), just so the merit of ordination has

neither measure nor number. This (for you is the second effect) of ordin(ation). [3.] (Fruition [= requital of deeds]), what is [this]? When you let come to fruition this merit for all goods of happiness in the saṃsāra,
(you will obtain(?) all) this. All [your] desires [such as] the dignity of Indra, the dignity of a cakravartin king,
and so on(will be fulfilled for you. But if) you let this [=merit] come to fruition with a mind filled with [life-]weariness for release from the saṃsāra,
[then] (you will be released from the) saṃsāra by [one of] three paths: ([the path] of the) Buddha, of the Pratyekabuddha [and] of the Arhat.
To whatever .... (you will turn to, release from the saṃsāra will be) yours. This for you is the thi(rd) effect of ordination.

comments.comment: The supplementation and commentaries follow .
According to : iv-v this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.
From this leaf 2 fragments are preserved: one from the left side of the leaf to the string hole, consisting of 2 pieces and about 7 cm wide, and the right half of of the leaf, about 14 cm wide.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 6
This leaf is in hand 3.
Instead of ikä, which would have to be supplemented to ikäṃ, one could also read itä or isä.
The gap contains about 14 akṣaras.
paramanuntameṃ for paramānuntameṃ; saṃvār for saṃvar.
onolmeṃtsana: for a possible further supplementation cf. line a 1.
The gap contains about 7 akṣaras.

With the help of (mo)tärcce ( b5), = Skt. harita, the meaning of motarcca(na), Pl. Fem. of an adjective, can be identified as ‘green’ (for more detail see ). In TA there is motarci (Nom.Sg.Fem.), which, according to , denotes a colour that is probably dark, but otherwise unidentifiable. Etymologically, this colour adjective must be connected to Slavic *modrъ ‘blue’ (Czech modrý, etc.).
The gap contains about 8 akṣaras.
etsuwai elauke wat ‘near or far’.
sanvar for saṃvar; wantarwameṃ for wäntarwameṃ.
wantarwameṃ sic! for wäntarwameṃ.
The gap contains about 9 akṣaras.
Mistaken wasaṃtpātäpi for wasaṃtpātäṣṣepi; yarpontse for yärpontse.
wasaṃtpātäpi sic! and to be corrected to wasaṃtpātäṣṣepi.
The gap contains about 7 akṣaras.
pkelyñe for pkelñe; krui for kwri.
saṃsārṣṣa sic! and to be corrected to saṃsārṣṣana.
The gap contains about 11 akṣaras.
cahhravārtti for cakravārtti; lantuñesa for lantuññesa.
The gap contains about 8 akṣaras.
The gap contains about 5 akṣaras.
pañäktiññe for pañäktäññe; prattika-pañäktiññe for pratika-pañäktäññe; arahanteññe for arhanteññe; ceś for kuceś.
The gap contains about 7 akṣaras.
Mistaken wasaṃtpāntse for wasaṃtpātäntse.
cäṅken·a· is unclear.
saṃtpāntse sic! and to be corrected to saṃtpātäntse.
The gap contains about 12 akṣaras.

line.tr: (Now I will proclaim to you what virtues) can be obtained (with the power of the three jewels). With the power of the three jewels

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: (the virtues of munificence ... can be obtained. Therefore one shall) create great belief in the three jewels.
... (If) you have never heard of the virtues of the three jewels, [then] (listen) now
with .... . The Buddha, [who is] equipped with virtues without measure [and] number, (is), briefly
[put], .... (virtuous(?)) and (sup)erior. In what way is he virtuous? All that (the) saṃsāra
(beings need for [their] release, [all] this) he knew. And all that the saṃsāra beings did not know,
([all] that he taught them) .... In this way he is virtuous. In what way is he superior?
(In numberless births(??)), for the sake (of a single dictum [subhāṣita]), hands [and] feet, nose [and] ears, skin [and] bl(ood),
...... (all) dear [and] enjoyable things, all he has given away [and] from a mountain he has
(cast himself. When he) was a king (named)...., (he) sacrificed himself for a single śloka ....

According to : iv-v this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.
The right half of a leaf, consisting of 4 pieces, about 13 cm wide.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 6
This leaf is in hand 3.
naumiyentats for naumiyentaṃts.

maiyyātse for maiyyātstse.
At the beginning of this line about 16 akṣaras are missing.
klyauṣu for keklyauṣu.
klyauṣu sic! and to be corrected to keklyauṣu.
At the beginning of this line about 12 akṣaras are missing.
. The first word in this line cannot be supplemented to (palsko)sa.
At the beginning of this line about 17 akṣaras are missing.
krentaunatse for krentaunatstse.
At the beginning of this line about 15 akṣaras are missing.
aiksante is Pt.III of aik- ‘know’. ekasta ( b3), too, is clearly Pt.III, albeit listed as a Pt.I by mistake in , § 436,2.
At the beginning of this line about 17 akṣaras are missing.
krentaunatse for krentaunatstse.
pruccamo ‘excellent’. An Obl.Sg.Fem. prucamñai is attested in b2.
At the beginning of this line about 17 akṣaras are missing.
paiyne for paine.
At the beginning of this line about 13 akṣaras are missing.

The supplementation to larona is prompted by a4 lāre ṣek cäñcre. rintsete sic! for rintsate.
At the beginning of this line about 17 akṣaras are missing.
ṣey for ṣai; mistaken penesa for pernesa; laṃṣate for laṃṣāte.
penesa sic! and to be corrected to pernesa. laṃṣa to be corrected and supplemented to laṃṣā(te).

transcription.prose: ·v·dguṇā sarveṣāṃ

line.tr: (With) awe [and] shyness .... (thus you shall) love ([your] teacher like) father [and] mother ....

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5

line.tr: .... speech [and] instruction (by [your] teacher) [you] shall receive with [an inclination of your] head....
... Why so? Because [only] the one, who [possesses] moral conduct, [is] a monk. Moral con(duct) ....
.... Moral conduct is the sign of all virtues. Mor(al conduct)....
.... is a saying by (the Buddha), the teacher ....
.... your merits ... for(?) all. Thus ....
... (If(?)) .... is, [then] you can obtain this with your whole self through moral conduct. ...
... study (of the ...) [and] moral conduct [in] service, however, [are] this, through the power of which (one) ....
.... is not (obtainment(?)). So far(?) as the gods [such as] Viṣṇu, Mahe(śvara and so on) are, ....
.... (all that(?)) you obtain through the power of the (three diamonds). Exactly therefore....

comments.comment: The supplementation and commentaries follow .
According to : iv-v the ms. comes either from Qizil of from Tumšuq.
could belong to this leaf, cf. .

A larger fragment from the centre of a leaf, to the right of the string hole, consisting of 4 pieces, about 9 cm wide. The exact place of this leaf within the whole ms. is uncertain since the leaf number is not preserved, but it seems to belong towards the end.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 6
larauwñe for larauñe.
pātär mātärne sic! For this line cf. b 2.
welyñe for welñe; enäṣṣälyñe for enäṣṣälñe; wärpanale for wärpanalle.
enäṣṣälyñe sic! The text in this line is repeated word by word in b4.
kātsifor kāttsi; mistaken papāṣoñe for papāṣṣorñe; papāṣorñe for papāṣṣorñe.
papāṣoñe sic! and to be corrected to papāṣorñe. The last word in this line is probably also papāṣorñe or a derivation of it.
papāṣorñe for papāṣṣorñe; krentaunäts for krentaunaṃts.
krentaunäts sic! and to be corrected to krentaunaṃts. The last word in this line could once again be papāṣorñe (cf. line a 3).
The final syllable in this line ([c·]) could also be [v·], but hardly d·.
The remains of a verse in Sanskrit are too scanty to allow for identification.
ramtä for ramt.
papāṣorñesa for papāṣṣorñesa; mistaken papāṣorñe for papāṣṣorñe.
The only way to supplement the final word in this line would be the sub. kallaṃ.
āklyilyñe for aklyilñe.
papārñe sic! and to be corrected to papāṣorñe.
eṣke for eṃṣke.
viṣnu sic! for viṣṇu.
kälpāstä for kälpāst.
The beginning of this line may perhaps be supplemented to tarya naumiyentaṃts.

line.tr: ... you shall have. ([You] shall) take the three diamonds [as] teachers. ....
.... It is (the bidding(?) of the Buddha(?), the teacher(?)): One shall be wise, the head ....

.... (And exactly this take to your heart): May, through (this good) deed, (the virtues [of] munificence [dāna], moral conduct [śīla], wisdom [prajñā], patience [kṣānti], energy [vīrya] [and] meditation [dhyāna], and so on), that (are conductive) to this garb,
be mine! || ||

According to : iv-v this ms. comes either from Qizil or from Tumšuq.

A larger fragment from the centre of a leaf, with only one side written on, about 5-10 cm wide. This seems to be the final leaf in the ms., as the text appears to end in line 4. The leaf number is not preserved.

The original ms. was 29 cm wide and 5.6 cm high, with the string hole 6.5 cm from the left margin. It was written by at least three hands: scribe 1, a beautiful, delicate script, from leaf 1 to 11 a1; scribe 2, distinguished by a number of orthographical idiosyncrasies/errors, from leaf 11 a1 to and including 19; scribe 3 from leaf 20 to end. The final leaves A and B and may have been written either by scribe 2 or a fourth hand. Cf. : v, 2, 6
takañ-cä for tākañ-c; eṅkaṣäle for eṅkaṣṣälle.

takañcä sic! and to be corrected to tākañcä. The last word in this line is to be supplemented to either eṅkaṣälona or eṅkaṣäle. Both constructions, personal as well as impersonal with an obliquus object, appear in this ms. On this cf. . and 22ff.
watkäṣälyñe for watkäṣṣälñe; maimatse for maimantse; mäskele for mäskelle; aścä for āśc.
The beginning of this line may perhaps be supplemented to (pañäktents)e (watkä)ṣälyñe.
The beginning of this line may perhaps be supplemented to (c)e (kr)e(nt yā)morsa.

It cannot be determined any more whether the text ends after this line, or whether originally a colophon followed. As far as can be told from this fragment, the space below this line seems to be blank. The verso side is blank as well.

line.tr: ... || This fifth art has been finished writing. || ...

comments.comment: In view of the leaf number ‹8› of , the small effaced spot left of the leaf number ‹9› may be ignored. While two other leaves of this manuscript ( and ) have no leaf numbers preserved, the leaf number of is illegible. The right margin is not preserved, but there are no akṣaras missing.
siddham̐: the i-stroke of ‹si› is ornamentally lengthened around the akṣara. This word opens the sixth section of the syllabary, which consists of consonant ligatures with the vowel a (cf. ).

provenance.expeditionCode: T III Š 77, T III Š 63, T III Š 98

transcription.prose:
(ṇam) (ṇa)ḥ ta tya tra tla tva tma tta tna tṇa tca tña rta tṛ tṝ tam taḥ tha thya thra thla thva thma thta thna thṇa thca thña rtha thṛ thṝ
tham thaḥ da dya dra dla dva dma dta dna dṇa dca dña rda dṛ dṝ dam daḥ dha dhya dhra dhla dhva dhma dhta dhna dhṇa dhca dhña rdha dhṛ dhṝ dha
m dhaḥ na nya nra nla n(v)a (nma) nta nna nṇa nca rna nṛ nṝ nam naḥ pa pya pra pla pva pma pta pna pṇa pca pña rpa pṛ pṝ pam
paḥ pha phya phra (phla) (phva) (phma) (phta) (phna) phṇa phca phña rpha phṛ phṝ pham phaḥ ba bya (bra) bla bva bma bta bna bṇa bca bña rba bṛ bṝ ba
m baḥ bha bhy(a) (bhra) (bhla) (bhva) (bhma) (bhta) (bhna) bhṇa bhca bhña rbha bhṛ bhṝ bham bhaḥ ma mya mra mla mva mma mta mna mṇa mca mña rma mṛ mṝ ma
m maḥ ya yya yra yla yva yma yta yna yṇa y(ca) yña rya yṛ yṝ yam yaḥ ra rya rra rla rva rma (r)ta rna rṇa
(rca) rña rṛ rṝ ram raḥ la lya lra lva lma lta lna lṇa lca lña rla lṛ lṝ lam laḥ ca cya cra cla cva cma
(cta) (cna) (cṇa) cca cña rca cṛ cṝ cam caḥ śa śya śra śla śva śma śta śna śṇa śca śña rśa śṛ śṝ śam śaḥ ṣa ṣya ṣra ṣla ṣva ṣma ṣta ṣna ṣṇa

comments.comment: If is leaf number 9, this is leaf number 10. Interestingly, this leaf seems to be missing on the right about as much as is missing on the left. This could mean that the leaves lay upon each other, but reversed.

rṛ rṝ: these akṣaras are technically to be transliterated like this, but it should be noted that ‹rṛ› equals Tocharian ‹_r_a›, which is never transliterated as ‹r_r_a›. On the other hand, the akṣara ‹rṝ› does not occur in Tocharian and can thus be transliterated like this without any problem.
: ‹lla› is omitted between ‹lra› and ‹lva›.

(si)ddhaṁ kra krā kri krī kru krū kre krai kro krau kraṃ kraḥ khra khrā khri khrī khru khrū khre khrai khro khrau khraṃ khraḥ gra grā gri grī gru grū gre (grai)

line.tr: ... || This [is] the third art. || ...

comments.comment: On IDP, recto and verso are reversed.
lyo: the vowel diacritic is lowered, apparently because of the length stroke of the ‹yyū› above.
: With || säs trit amok || the third section of vocalised ligatures with ‹y› ends, and with (si)ddham̐ the fourth section of vocalised ligatures with medial ‹r› begins ().
kr[ū]: the length of the vowel is indicated by a small horizontal arc on the right side of the ‹r›-element. This length stroke is hardly visible, but traces can be discerned.

line.tr: ... (in) the 38th (week)
... it goes into solidity ...
... all (limbs?) ...
... is attached to ...
... these ...
... is attached to ...
... has arisen ...
... the wind of fate (karma) ...

comments.comment: A fragment from the left side of a leaf: upper, lower and left margins are preserved. Black lineage.
l··: the l could be in a ligature, and it could have an ā-vowel. Thus, a restoration to lyā 'limbs' is a possibility, cf. b1 puk lyā āps·.
l rītwoṣ, l rītwo(ṣ): the l most probably is to be restored as a com. ending °(aśśä)l.
rpaṣi: probably a ṣi-adjective derived from a noun in -rp. According to , there are only three possibilities: tarp 'pond', sparp 'rope', and warp 'enclosure'.
: cf. e.g. b4 cesäm ṣpät koṃsā 'by this week', lit. 'by these seven days'.

lypurṣi wa·t: even though the element before the t is illegible, a reading wa(n)t is suggested by the expression 'wind of fate' in a2 lyalypurṣināṃ waṃtyo and a7 lyalypurṣi want. ca could have to be restored to ca(mi) 'its, his', among others.

recto.line: ca rtā pa ṢAṃ śwā tsi yo kts[i] ///
kā¯ ¯K prā KA rna slu ne yaṃ ///

verso.line: se mā [l]y· lypu RA ṣta tmu¯ ///
wso kaṃ • TA mne¯ ¯K klo tsma [l]· ///

transcription.prose:
t·ktä || /// (mā)
car tāpaṣ-äṃ śwātsi yoktsi /// (o)
kāk prākär nasluneyaṃ ///
se mā ly(a)lypuräṣ tatmu ///
wsokaṃ • tämnek klots mal(añ) ///
l·ne l(k)ātsi ·o ///

line.tr: ... the mother will eat its food and drink ...
... until ... it goes into solid existence ...
... son... not having left ... is born ...
... happy. • So the ear and the nose ...
... to see ...

comments.comment: The left and lower (recto) margins are preserved. If the fragment belongs to the same manuscript as , the leaf number may be ‹4··›, i.e. a number in the four hundreds. The original number of lines would then be 6; b1-3 would have to be renumbered as b4-6.
: equally possible, of course, is a conditional construction. Instead of (mā)car, one could as well restore (pā)car, (pra)car, etc.
: cf. a1 okāk prākär nasluneya(ṃ) yäṣ.
se: there are not many words ending in se with a vowel directly preceding (cf. ). The most likely reading seems se 'son'.
klots: it is remarkable that the word for 'ear' seems to be in the singular.
[l·n]e: possibly a verbal noun in -lune.

recto.line: ṢA[ṃ] || pa ñca ga ti n[aṃ] ///

worpuṣ ṣeñc : c·  /// 
 ṣäṃ || pañcagatinaṃ (||)  /// 
 rackiñ puk wā  /// 

             ///

lnäṣṣ oki epreri(s)  ///

line.tr: they were surrounded ...
... || pañcagatinaṃ (||) ...///
... armies ... all ...
... direction ...
... resounds as it were (in the surface) of the sky ...
... they are all mixed together ...

comments.comment: The left margin and seemingly the upper margin (recto) are preserved.

rackiñ: although the reading is not certain, this seems to be the only possible one. The word ratäk 'army' is usually supposed to inflect as nātäk 'lord', but the fact that the obl.pl. rackis shows unexpected c and i () suggests another inflexion for the plural, which would fit rackiñ in fact well.
(kä)lnäṣṣ: Restoration due to Ilya Itkin (p.c. 5 July 2014).
: cf. b4 epreriss āntaṃ.
triwanträ: cited by and .
: cf. a4 ywār tr(i)weñci.

·s· ///
kaśal ma ///
empelyā(s) ///
krutsi lya ///
säm krutsi /// (o)
ṅknaśśäl ṣya(k) ///
m klopa(nt) ///

line.tr: ... together ...
... terrible ...
... together with the man ...
... sorrows ...

comments.comment: The left and possibly the lower (recto) margin are preserved.
kaśal ma ///: this combination occurs in b1 kaśal masäk and b6 kaśal malkam.

line.tr: ... the animals devour (?) (him) ...
... there [and] there ...
... in small measure ...
... so a liar ...
... this extraordinarily tender ...
... they ... him ... all [his] body ...
... burns as it were ...

comments.comment: Upper and lower margins are preserved.
: cf. b6 lwā tspokinc-äṃ. The meaning 'enjoy' () is based on the etymological connection with tspok 'taste' and does not follow from the passages where the verb is attested.
: cf. b5 cami ṣoṅkātsāśśi. This word may suggest appurtenance to the Garbhasūtra.
smā(lok): Possibly a trace of the upper part of the l-ligature is seen to the right. This restoration is due to Ilya Itkin (p.c. 8 September 2016).
4: This reading, which confirms the order of recto and verso, is due to Ilya Itkin (p.c. 8 September 2016).
ṣoṅkātsāñ: This reading, instead of ṣoṅkātsāś(śi), is due to Ilya Itkin (p.c. 8 September 2016).
: See .
/// ṣiṃñc-äṃ: possibly (klyo)ṣiṃñc-äṃ 'may they hear him'.
tsäknäṣtr-änn o(ki): This reading, instead of tsäknäṣtr-än no(ṣ), is due to Sergey Malyshev (p.c. 8 September 2016).

line.tr: ... in the Trayastriṃśa [heaven], (in the town) Sudarśana ...
... the Buddha heard [it] ...
... when ...
... the Buddha, the teacher, ...
... having become. Not ...
... births ...
... and carrying out ...
... says: «So it will be!»

comments.comment: The upper margin (recto) and the right side of the string hole, covering lines 3 and 4, are preserved. Effaced black lineage, also vertically to indicate the string hole.
: cf. a2, b1 tāpātriśaṃ

line.tr: ... companion ...
... to be desired divine ...
... (burnt) by the fires of ...
... the lake of impurity ...
... may I throw. ...
... sweet ... for me (?) ...

comments.comment: An effaced vertical black line at the end of the top line of the recto and the bottom line of the verso is tentatively taken as an indication of the string hole (see ). This is the basis for the line numbering.
: cf. a5 onmīṣinās poränyo, a4 kleśāṣinās poräṃ.

/// (wä)rtāṣimār: this is one of the very few possibilities, perhaps the only one, for a 1sg.opt.mid. to a causative verb to a root in -rt. This is without doubt the form tāṣimār cited as an opt. to täs- 'put' by . As I have argued, this is morphologically not possible ().

recto.line: [¯T] ṣPA tkoṃ saṃ ca mi ā ///
tmāṃ T[M]Aṃ saṃ TA¯ ¯R ce SA¯ ¯M ///

verso.line: ñca pā tTA rnaṃ || taṃ ne wKA ///

line.tr: ... firm ...
... as it were ... completely ...
... in seven days his ...
... 10,000 are produced ... these ...
... surrounded all around ...
... brahmins (?) ... separately (?) ...
... (some are) red, some (are) ...
... without illness ...
... of all those ...
... || pañcapāttärnaṃ || In this way ...
... each carrying out [his] task ...
... then ...

comments.comment: The left and lower (recto) margins are preserved. The leaf number could be longer: in view of the high position of ‹4› and ‹100›, a ten as well as a digit may have been lost.
ā ///: if this is a Garbhasūtra fragment, a possible restoration would be (ā)riñc 'heart'.
mnāñ: the only two possibilities seem to be (brā)mnāñ and (ṣā)mnāñ.
ṣo(maṃ): in view of the preceding pl.f. rätraṃ, this may be a pl.f. form too.
pontāśśi: most probably the form cited as "Frgm." in .
(|| pa)ñcapāttärnaṃ ||: certainly a variant of a4 pañcapātraṃ, b3 (|| pa)ñcapātraṃ ||.

recto.line: /// ·[mo] lī skā rplu ne MA ska ///

verso.line: /// [ko] sne nu to ṣtri wr[a] MAṃ ṣya ///

line.tr: ... having ... (from) all sorrows ...
... says: «I am ready» ...
... (this ?) is descending of birth ...
... but how many together with these three things ...
... it takes birth (?). If ...
... female ...

comments.comment: At the right side, the margin or the edge of the string hole might be preserved. The lower margin (recto) might also be preserved. Faint traces of black lineage can be discerned.
: cf. .
(cmo)l(l eṃ)tsäṣtär: cf. b2 cmol eṃtsäṣtär. I owe the restoration of a geminate ll to Sergey Malyshev (p.c.).

line.tr: ... to touch ...
... memory ... near ...
... fruit of ... they ... divine ...
... without [any] other way. 1.
... towards the Buddha, the teacher ...
... was proclaimed, honourable ...
... receive the miserable beings ...
... in your power ...
... good ...

comments.comment: The right margin is preserved.
(s)s oko: certainly oko is preceded by a genitive, e.g. pñintwiss 'of the merits'. The genitive ending is often geminated before oko.
ceṣ ñäkciyā: ceṣ is nom.pl.m., while ñäkciyā is a pl.f., so probably obl.pl.f. ñäkciyā(s).
(ākṣi)ññu: alternatively, (okṣi)ññu or (kākñä)ññu are possible.

line.tr: ... take birth ...
... they are away (?) for him. ...
... the city of lyārp (?). (On) earth ...
... if he was ...
... it sprouts. ...
... taken. Therefore ...

comments.comment: cmoll e: certainly a form of ents- 'take'.
wenat_r_a: the ‹na› and the ‹t_r_a› are connected, but not as a virāma (pace ). This is the form cited in ().
: the word division is uncertain.

recto.line: /// [i] me KA lp[o] yo ka ñ[i] ///

verso.line: /// n[e] o te TA preṃ ci ñcro ///

line.tr: ... which not ...
«... give him ...!» Then Nanda ... the Buddha ...
... has got the memory ... thirsty ...
«... brother, tell me ...»
... Thereupon ...
... wide ... trusting ...
... (O how wonderful is ...!) O how wonderful is this pleasantness! ...
... he has a worthy head. O how wonderful ... divine (?) ...!
... divine ...

comments.comment: mpe: possible restorations include (wa)mpe 'jewel', (ā)mpe 'both', (ta)mpe 'power'.
ne: possibly an abstract, parallel to ciñcro(ne). This suggests that another ote täpreṃ preceded.

line.tr: ... he rode him/her, [if this is his/her] will or not ...
... has taught the teachings of the vedas ...
... but I ... sixty ...
... having heard this ...
... the ... of another forest ...
... of the beings ... each day ...

comments.comment: The lower margin (recto) is preserved.
klāṅka-ṃ: cf. .
: cf. b6 vedaśāstraṃ.
ñ(u)k nu: another possibility would be ñ (k)[a]knu. There is no vowel sign on top of the ‹ñ›, and there seems to be no ligature part below it, but a lower part ‹k› or ‹u› cannot be excluded.
(ā)ly(a)käñcaṃ: this variant is attested once more in a1, against ālakäñcaṃ in a3, a6, b5 ().

line.tr: ... Indra ...
... they know it manifestly. || ...
... (becomes?) visible in the monastery ...
... it was a task together with ... This ...
... seeing each other ... this ...
... as tasty as (they are) ...
... the force of passion ...
... coming together with ...

verso.line: /// pśa ñi sne prā kro n· ///

line.tr: ... turtles ...
... drink ...
... is born ...
... body without solidity ...
... ceasing ...

comments.comment: According to three different labels on the frame, this fragment may belong together with . The reason for this is evidently the word wālätkāñ, which occurs in line a2 of this fragment as well as in a5. I have not yet found more precise matches proving that the two fragments belong to the same leaf.
: cf. a5 tmäṣ tom wālätkāñ kaṣtyo miṣānt 'then these turtles were tortured by hunger'. The translation 'turtles' follows .
ts·ātär: perhaps ts(k)ātär 'will be pulled out', cf. a4 śākant 'were pulled out'.

line.tr: ... he goes over ...
... like ... very ...
... small ...
... strong ...
... hard [and] dry ...
... they take it ...

comments.comment: Traces of black ruling.
ṣoky=: since o-vocalism is excluded, I assume that the word ṣokyo is in sandhi here (cf. b7, b6).
cf. a2 tsraṃ āsraṃ.

line.tr: ... [she was] sitting on the grass ...
... Sundarī ... who ...
... tree ... in this birth ...
... Then the Buddha, the teacher, ...

comments.comment: sundhari: sic, certainly for sundari.

line.tr: ... on a (pāṇḍukambala) throne ...
... (with) a sweet laughing (voice) ...
... embraces divine ...
... having seen outer skin, breasts ...
... they go (= become?) satiated ...
... divine ...
... the Buddha ...

comments.comment: Faint traces of black ruling.
(pāṇḍukampa)l pārenā: cf. b5, a8, a5, b4.
: for the restoration, cf. .

yäksātär: the reading follows and . rather reads ksātär 'blinds' or 'is blinded'. This is indeed an option, but no subjunctive of ksā- is attested otherwise; it is also possible that kākso was an isolated, frozen preterite participle without accompanying finite forms.
lkoñcäs: theoretically, options are (kä)lkoñcäs, (pä)lkoñcäs, (mä)lkoñcäs, (sä)lkoñcäs.
: for the restoration, cf. .

line.tr: ... this earth ... houses ...
Īśvaradatte says, «...»
(...-) Soma says, «Hey, ...»
... with a diademe ...
... arisen ...

comments.comment: (i)śvaradatte: cf. a3, b1, b4, a5. On the basis of this name, appurtenance to the Garbhasūtra can provisionally be assumed.
some: cf. b7. It may also be the last part of a longer name.

secondary.siglum: Prelim. No. 200 (Prelim. No. is given as 203 in list of the State Library)

line.tr: ... pins ...
... || niṣkramāntaṃ || ...
... they oppress him. If ...
... he undergoes sorrows ...
... manifest ...

comments.comment: : the word division is uncertain. If klyor rkli is a writing error for klyor kli, the last word could be kliso 'slept', but the last akṣara can otherwise also be read s[i].
(kä)ltsnāntr-äṃ: cf. (who incorrectly cites the form as (kä)ltsnāträ-ṃ THT 1151 b1).

line.tr: ... may they be without illness!
... the land of Ārśi ...
... (may) they (be freed) from the sorrows! ...
... is attached to ...
... we make manifest ... All ...
... I ... towards the Buddha worth ...
... where the saṃsāra ...
... having lifted up [his] knees.

comments.comment: Part of the left side of a leaf: upper, lower and left margins (but not the string hole space) are preserved. This was apparently the last leaf of the manuscript, since the verso has only two lines while the remaining space is left blank. Of the leaf number can be read 〈[100]〉 〈60〉 〈8〉, but a digit above the 〈[100]〉 may have been lost. Both recto and verso are quite abraded.
tāki(ñc): tāki(m), tāki(ṣ) and tāki(mäs) are palaeographically impossible; tāki(ñc) is therefore the most likely.
(pākra)śik: among the very few words ending in single śi (cf. ), pākraśi is the only likely option here. The final -k is the emphatic particle.

line.tr: ... from the ...
... he went to ... Then ...
... for the benefit ...
... like ... put into paryaṅka position (= cross-legged) ...
... knowing the thought[s] of others ...
... he made manifest [his] knowledge of the prescriptions (?) ...
... to shake the earth completely ...

comments.comment: (v)idhijñāṃ: apparently borrowed from a Skt. vidhijñāna 'knowledge of the rules; knowledge of the prescriptions' (this word is not recorded in IV: 116a or ).

line.tr: ... of the senses ...
... wash with warm water ...
... in this way ...
... they suck ...
... in this way passion ...
... or of sorrow. He ...
... or of sorrow ...

comments.comment: ki: the reading is uncertain; [k](l)[o](p) 'sorrow' would also be possible. One of the very few words beginning with ki would be kip 'shame'.

line.tr: ... of wisdom ...
... in the world ... a place ...
... the ... of the world; one who makes forget the sorrows; with ...
... one who begets omniscient [Buddhas]; the grandfather [and] mother of the world; ... the good ...
... of all virtues; evils [and] offences ...
...(8)6 Joint [and] connection of moral behaviour; ... of endurance ...
... 87 ... of the jewels ...
... (food) [and] drink ... lovely ...

comments.comment: Striking is the lack of any finite verb form in the fragment: as far as can be established with the fragmentary portions preserved, the text consists of a series of nominal phrases consisting of a head noun and an adjective, genitive, locative, object, etc. In style it thus reminds of for instance the Buddhastotra with epithets in alphabetical order edited by . Indeed, this fragment seems to be part of a Buddhastotra as well, but so far no system in the sequence of the epithets can be found. The asignment of recto and verso is uncertain.

Even though pāda-marking punctuation seems to be lacking completely, the whole text is probably metrical, witness the strophe numbers b2 (8)6 and b3 87. The metre is most probably 4 x 7¦7, in view of the fact that in all lines sequences of 4 and 3 syllables alternate: a1: (ai)ś(a)mñeṣṣe + 3 syllables a2: 4 syllables + śaiṣṣene a3: 2 syllables + kkenta śaiṣṣentse a3: marsärṣṣañca läklenta a4: tanmäṣṣeñca poyśīnta a4: āwe mācer śaiṣṣentse b1: 1 syllable + ·ñ· ponta krentaunats b1: yolaiññenta träṅkonta b2: meska raitwe śilaṣṣi b2: kälṣamñeṣṣa + 3 syllables b3: naumyentaṣ(ṣ)· + 3 syllables b4: 2 syllables + yoktsi ciñca(r)e The only places where pāda-marking punctuation might be found are b1 krentaunat_s\•, if the virāma dot replaces the pāda-final dot; and a4 śaiṣṣentse, which has a remarkable extra stroke on top of the last akṣara. If the metre is indeed 4 x 7¦7, the length of one line was approximately 50 syllables (4 x 14 = 56 syllables from 86 to 87; but since 87 stands about 7 akṣaras right of 86, the line length is 56 – 7 = 49).
(ai)ś(a)mñeṣṣe: possibly followed by sārathiṃ 'charioteer', cf. a5 = a5.
/// – kk[e]nta: possibly the e-vowel is actually r. A reading to consider would be [y](ä)[r]kk(e)nta.
mar_s_arṣṣañca: the second r is miswritten for e; read mar_s_aṣṣeñca (see ; .
: cf. .
āwe: the translation 'grandfather' of is here provisionally followed, even though this definitely needs further confirmation.
śaiṣṣentse: a stroke on top of the last akṣara is probably to be ignored.

meska raitwe śilaṣṣi: This sequence is difficult to analyse. The easiest seems to take meska raitwe as a juxtaposed meske raitwe 'joint [and] connection'. However, the following śilaṣṣi can only be a nom.pl.m., so that the two words meske raitwe together would be a plural, a construction not normally found in Tocharian (perhaps this is a calque on Sanskrit?). Not probable is an interpretation meska rai twe 'O joint, you!' with meska as a vocative, because then śilaṣṣi would be even more difficult (the regular vocative would be śilaṣṣu).
yoktsi: there are traces under the first akṣara that cannot belong to it if this reading is correct.

line.tr: /// (the monk commits) SA.-sin. (6) ///
/// the monks should be conducted from the community ///
/// he does, the monk (commits) SA.-sin. (7) ///
/// he accuses of [Pār.]-sin (without) [ground]) ///
/// (the monk) commits SA.-sin. 8 If (a monk) ///
/// Obtained the cause ..., (he accuses) of Pār.-sin ///
/// in order to bewitch, the monk (commits) SA.-(sin. 9) ///
/// he does ..., the monk (should be instructed by) the monks ///
/// in (various) ways, Buddha, the teacher ///
/// [he should be instructed]. If he abandons, it is good. ///

line.tr: /// (If a monk), is knowing, (and) pours out the water containing animals on the clay (or orders to pour out) ///
Whichever monk consciously pours out water with animals in it on clay, (or has it) poured out over it, … ([commits] a pātayantika offence.)
/// (the monk) commits (Pāt.-sin.). 19 If a monk builds a large cell, ///
/// builds (it) or orders to build (it) [more than that], the monk (commits) Pāt.-sin. 20 ///
/// (If a monk is not approved) to preach the law to the nuns (by the community) ///
/// if the preaching of the law to the nuns continues (till) the sunset ///
/// for the sake of (the gain), the monks (preach the law) the nuns ///
/// (if a monk through agreement) with the nuns goes on the way, except for some occasions ///

/// the monk commits Pāt.-sin. 26 If a monk to an unrelated nun ///

line.tr: ... king Prasenajit ...
... he urged [him] from [his] sleep (?). ... of the Buddha ...
... having ..., king Prasenajit ...
... so these brahmins ...
... may be answered. || Having heard this ...
... through the wisdom, he himself ...

comments.comment: In one frame with . Since the fragment is damaged in the same way as , the two fragments must have been lying on each other.
/// säm: A reading säm requires a construction säm prasenaji wäl 'this king Prasenajit'; a reading (ce)säm requires heavy object fronting.
(ṣä)pnäṣ: pnäṣ could theoretically also be a verb form, cf. b2 pnäṣṣ-äṃ.
sam: Since mätne probably starts a clause, sam probably ends a clause. Therefore, it is more likely to be a 1sg. verb form than the word 'same'.
_m _m_a: the first _m seems to be connected to the left so that it would be virāma position, but at the same time there is a second _m, which makes a ligature reading more likely.
(wä)tkāṣäl: the akṣara traces before tkā are compatible with w, but not with e.g. pyu (cf. b1 pyutkāṣäl).
näṃ: If a spelling tsäṃ without Fremdzeichen is admitted (cf. in particular a3), a reading (tsopa)t(s)äṃ (cf. b3) could also be possible.

comments.comment: In one frame with . Since the fragment is damaged in the same way as , the two fragments must have been lying on each other. However, they need not be from the same manuscript.
